div1.p: THE ROAD TO RUIN: A COMEDY.
AS ACTED AT THE LONDON and DUBLIN THEATRES.
DUBLIN; Printed for J. BRAGG, Crow-Street, 1792.

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.stage: Enter, driving a boy across the stage.

lg.l: AWAY! 'Sblood! Run for the Author! We can do nothing till he appears.
Tell him in less than five minutes we shall have the house about our ears!
Oh sirs! The prompter has mislaid the prologue, and we are all a mort,
I suppose our friends above yonder will soon be making pretty sport;
For pity's sake, suffer us to go on without it—Good, dear sirs, do!
'Twas most abominably dull—Zounds! There stands the writer. Well, It's very true.
One of our te tum ti heroes was to have spoken it, who measure nonsense out by the yard;
And our chief hope was you'd make too much noise for it to be heard.
The author had mounted on the stilts of oratory and elocution:
Not but he had a smart touch or two, about Poland, France, and the—the revolution;
Telling us that Frenchman, and Polishman, and every man is our brother;
And that all men, ay, even poor negro men, have a right to be free one as well as another!
Freedom at length, said he, like a torrent is spreading and swelling,
To sweep away pride and reach the most miserable dwelling:
To ease happiness, art, science, wit, and genius to give birth;
Ay, to fertilize a world, and renovate old earth!
Thus he went on, not mentioning a word about the play:
For he says prologues are blots, which ought to be wiped away:
A gothic practice, and in spite of precedent, not the better for being old,
For, if we tell any part of the plot, it then becomes a tale twice told,
And such twice telling can rarely once excite our wonder:
Ergo, he that says nothing is least likely to blunder.
Since therefore prologues are bad things at best, pray, my good friends,
Never mind the want of one, but live in hopes the play will make amends.

div1.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE,
div1.p: N. B. The passages marked with double commas are omitted in representation.

set.p: SCENE, London. Time not twenty-four hours.

div3.head: SCENE I. The House of DORNTON.

sp.p: PAST two o'clock and not yet returned!—Well, well!—It's my own fault!—Mr. Smith!

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Dornton.
sp.p: Is Mr. Sulky come in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you sure Harry Dornton said he should return to-night?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And you don't know where he is gone?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: He did not tell me, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Angrily] I ask you if you know!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I believe to Newmarket, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You always believe the worst!—I'll sit up no longer—Tell the servants to go to bed—And do you hear, should he apply to you for money, don't let him have a guinea.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I have done with him; he is henceforth no son of mine! Let him starve!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He acts very improperly, sir, indeed.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Improperly! How? What does he do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir! [Alarmed.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Have you heard any thing of—?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: [Confused] No—No, sir—Nothing—Nothing but what you yourself tell me.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Then how do you known he has acted improperly

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He is certainly a very good-hearted young gentleman, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Good-hearted! How dare you make such an assertion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How dare you, Mr. Smith, insult me so? Is not his gaming notorious; his racing, driving, riding, and associating with knaves, fools, debauchees, and black legs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Upon my word, sir—I—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But it's over! His name has this very day been struck out of the firm! Let his drafts be returned. It's all ended! [Passionately] And observe, not a guinea! If you lend him any yourself I'll not pay you. I'll no longer be a fond doting father! Therefore take warning! Take warning, I say! be his distress what it will, not a guinea! Though you should hereafter see him begging, starving in the streets, not so much as the loan or the gift of a single guinea! [With great passion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I shall be careful to observe your orders, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sir! [Terror] Why, would you see him starve?—Would you see him starve and not lend him a guinea? Would you sir? Would you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir!—Certainly not, except in obedience to your orders!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Amazement and compassion] And could any orders justify your seeing a poor unfortunate youth, rejected by his father, abandoned by his friends, starving to death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: There is no danger of that, sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I tell you the thing shall happen! He shall starve to death! [Horror at the supposition] I'll never look on him more as a son of mine; and I am very certain, when I have forsaken him, all the world will forsake him too. [Almost in tears.] Yes, yes! He is born to be a poor wretched outcast!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I hope, sir, he still will make a fine man.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Will!—There is not a finer, handsomer, nobler looking youth in the kingdom; no not in the world!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: I mean a worthy good man, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How can you mean any such thing! The company he keeps would corrupt a saint.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Sir, if you will only tell me what your pleasure is, I will endeavour to act like a faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I know you are a faithful servant, Mr. Smith.— [Takes his hand] I know you are—But you—You are not a father.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. SULKY, and Mr. SMITH goes off.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Sulky, have you heard any thing of him?

sp.speaker: Sulky.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And, hay—?[Excessively impatient] Any thing consoling, any thing good?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: No?—No, say you!—Where is he? What is he about?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Don't—? You love to torture me, sir! You love to torture me.

sp.speaker: Sul,
sp.p: Humph.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: For heaven's sake tell me what you have heard!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I love to torture you.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Put me out of my pain! If you are not a tiger, put me out of my pain! [There; read!

p.stage: [Reluctantly drawing a newspaper out of his pocket.]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Worse.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mercy defend me!—Where? What?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The first paragraph in the postscript: the beginning line in capitals.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Reads] The junior partner of the great banking house, not a mile from the Post-office, has again been touched at Newmarket, for upward of ten thousand pounds— [Pause] It can't be!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why, can it?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How do you know? What proof have you that this is not a lie?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: His own hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Bills at three days sight to the full amount have already been presented.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And accepted?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But!—Why!—Were you mad, Mr. Sulky? Were you mad?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I soon shall be.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Is not his name struck off the firm?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: They were dated two days before.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The credit of my house begins to totter!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Well it may!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What the effect of such a paragraph may be I cannot tell!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can—Ruin.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you serious, sir?

sp.speaker: Sul,
sp.p: I am not inclined to laugh—A run against the house, stoppage, disgrace, bankruptcy.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Really, Mr Sulky, you—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes, I know I offend. I was bred in your house, you used me tenderly, I served you faithfully, and you admitted me a partner. Don't think I care for myself. No, I can sit at the desk again. But You! You! First man of the first commercial city on earth, your name in the Gazette? Were it mine only I would laugh at it. What am I? Who cares for me?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: "Where is the vile—?"

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Who can tell? With his lords and his ladies, his court friends and his Newmarket friends, his women of wit and his men of soul, his blue stockings and his black legs!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Calling] Mr Smith!—Thomas!—William!
Call all the servants together, Mr Smith; clerks, footmen, maids, every soul! Tell them their young master is a scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Mr Smith
sp.p: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sir?— [His anger recurring] Bid them shut the door in his face! I'll turn the first away that lets him set foot in this house ever again!

sp.speaker: Mr Smith
sp.p: Very well, sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, sir? Damn your very well, sir! I tell you it is not very well, sir. He shall starve, die, rot in the street! Is that very well, sir?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Has a noble heart. A fond father's heart. The boy was a fond youth—But he spoiled him; and now he quarrels with himself and all the world, because he hates his own folly. [Distant knocking heard at the streetdoor.] So! Here is the youth returned [Knocking again.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. Dornton, followed by Servants.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Don't stir! On your lives, don't go to the door! Are the bolts and locks all fastened?

sp.speaker: Servants
sp.p: All, sir. [Knocking.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Don't mind his knocking! Go to bed every foul of you instantly, and fall fast asleep!—He shall starve in the streets! [Knocking again] Fetch me my blunderbuss! Make haste! [Exeunt.

head.stage: Scene changes to the Street before the Door.

sp.speaker: Postillion
sp.p: We smoked along, your honour!

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: [Knocks] I know you did. Had you been less free with your whip you would have been half a crown richer. Your next step should be to turn drummers, and handle the cat o' nine tails.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: It is very late you honour!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Be gone! I'll give you no more. [Knocks, Exeunt Postillions:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Throwing up the sash and presenting the blunderbuss, Mr Sulky behind,] Knock again, you scoundrel, and you shall have the full contents loaded to the muzzle, rascal!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: So! I suspected dad was in his tantarums.

sp.speaker: Milford
sp.p: You have given him some cause:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Very true [To his father] Consider, my dear sir, the consequences of lying out all night;

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Be gone, villian:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bad women, sir; damps, night air!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Watch-houses, pick-pockets, cut-throats;

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Come, come, sir— [Shutting down the window]

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: We shall not get in:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pshaw! How little do you know of my father, the door will open in less than fifteen seconds;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Done, for a hundred:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Done, done, [They take out their watches and the door opens] I knew you were had; double or quits we find the cloth laid and supper on the table; [Exeunt into the house:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: No, It won't do,

head.stage: Scene changes to the former Apartment.

div3.stage: Enter HARRY DORNTON, MILFORD, and Footman,

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: My old master is in a bitter passion, sir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I know it:

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: He is gone down to turn the servant out of doors that let you in:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Is he? Then go you and let your fellow-servant in again:

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I dare not sir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then I must. [Exit

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: He enquired who was with my young master,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Well:

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: And when he heard it was you, sir, he was ten times more furious, [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: All's well that ends well. This has been a cursed losing voyage, Milford:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I am a hundred and fifty in,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And I ten thousand out!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I believe I had better avoid your father for the present,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think you had. Dad considers you as my tempter, the cause of my ruin,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And I being in his debt, he conceives he may treat me without ceremony.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay, damn it, Jack, do him justice; it is not the money you had of him, but the ill advice he imputes to you that galls him:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I hear he threatens to arrest me;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, he has threatened to strike my name out of the firm, and disinherit me, a thousand times:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Oh, but he has been very serious in menacing me,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And me too.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You'll be at the tennis-court to morrow?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: What, not to see the grand match?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Oh yes, you will.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I am determined:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes, over night, you'll waver in the morning;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, It is high time, Jack, to grow prudent:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, my plan is formed: I'll soon be out of debt,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How will you get the money?

sp.speaker: Mil,
sp.p: By calculation.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I am resolved on it. What! can't a man of invention and genius out-wit a black-leg?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "Yes, if he will be as great a scoundrel."

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: That's not necessary. A keen eye a contriving head, a lucky moment and a little algebra will rout the whole host. How many men of rank and honour, having lost their fortunes, have double recovered them

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And very honourably;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: who doubts it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Nobody, Nobody;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But pray Harry, what is it you find so attractive in my late father's amorous relict?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What the widow Warren?

sp.speaker: Mil,
sp.p: She seems to think and even reports you are to marry—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Marry? Her? A coquette of forty, who ridiculously apes all the airs of a girl! Fantastic, selfish and a fool! And marry? Disgusting idea! Thou wert philosophising as we drove on the condition of a post-horse—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: I would rather be a post-horse, nay the rascal that drives a post-horse, than the base thing thou hast imagined!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Then why are you so often there?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Because I can't keep away:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: What, it is her daughter, Sophia?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Lovely bewitching innocent!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The poor young thing is fond of you?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: I should be half mad if I though she was not, yet am obliged to half hope she is not!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: What a question! Am I not a profligate, and in all probability ruined?—Not even my father can overlook this last affair—No,—Heigho;

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The loss of my father's will, and the mystery made of its contents by those who witnessed it, are strange circumstances!

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: In which the widow triumphs. And you being a bastard, and left by law to starve, she willingly pays obedience to laws so wise.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: She refuses even to pay my debts.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: And the worthy alderman, your father, being overtaken by death in the south of France, carefully makes a will, and then as carefully hides it where it is not to be found; or commits it to the custody of some mercenary knave, who has made his market of it to the widow—So! here comes the supposed executor of this supposed will.
My dear Mr. Sulky, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sulky
sp.p: Very ill.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Indeed? I am very sorry! What's your disorder?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You,

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Ruin, bankruptcy, infamy!

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: The old story!

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: To a new tune.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You are—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: What, my good cynic?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: A fashionable gentleman.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: I know it,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: And fashionably ruined.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: No—I have a father,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Who is ruined likewise:

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Is the Bank of England ruined?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: I say ruined. Nothing less than a miracle can save the house. The purse of Fortunatus could not supply you,

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: No; it held nothing but guineas, notes, bills paper for me!

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Such effrontery is insufferable. For these five years, sir, you have been driving to ruin more furiously than—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: An ambassadour's coach on a birth night. I saw you were stammering for a simile.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Youth mounts the box, seizes the reins, and jehus headlong on in the dark; Passion and Prodigality blaze in the front, bewilder the coachman, and dazzle and blind the passengers; Wisdom, Prudence, and Virtue are overset and maimed or murdered; and at last Repentance, like the footman's flambeau lagging behind, lights us to dangers when they are past all remedy.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Your name is struck off the firm. I was the adviser

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: You are very kind, Mr Sulky,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Your father is at last determined.

sp.speaker: Har
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You'll find so! And what brought you here, sir?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: A chaise and four. [To Milford.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: It might have carried you to a safer place. When do you mean to pay your debts?

sp.speaker: Mil
sp.p: When my father's executor prevails on the widow Warren to do me justice.

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: And which way am I to prevail?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And which way am I to pay my debts?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You might have more modesty than insolently to come and brave one of your principal creditors, after having ruined his son by your evil counsel.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—Don't believe a word on't, my good grumbler; I ruined myself, I wanted no counsellor,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: My father died immensely rich; and, though I am what the law calls illegitimate, I ought not to starve

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You have had five thousand pounds, and are five more in debt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes, thanks to those who trust boys with thousands,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: You would do the same now you think yourself a man,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Firmly] Indeed I would not.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Had you been watching the widow at home, instead of galloping after a knot of gamblers and pickpockets, you might perhaps have done yourself more service:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Which way, sir?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The will of your late father is found.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Found?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I have received a letter, from which I learn it was at last discovered, carefully locked up in a private drawer, and that it is now a full month since a gentleman of Montpelier, coming to England, was entrusted with it. But no such gentleman has yet appeared.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: If it should have got into the hands of the widow—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Which I suspect it has,—You are a couple of pretty gentlemen! But beware: misfortune is at your heels, Mr. Dornton vows vengeance on you both, and justly. He is not gone to bed: and if you have confidence enough to look him in the face, I would have you stay where you are,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I neither wish to insult nor be insulted. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Do you know, sir, your father turned the poor fellow into the street, who compassionately opened the door for you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes; and my father knows I as compassionately opened the door for the poor fellow in return.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Very well, sir—Your fame is increasing daily:

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p: I am glad to hear it:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph! Then perhaps you have paragraphed yourself?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Paragraphed? What? Where?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: In the St. James's Evening:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Stating the exact amount:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Of my loss?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yours—You march through every avenue to fame, dirty, or clean,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well said!—Be witty when you can; sarcastic you must be, in spite of your teeth. But I like you the better. You are honest, you are my cruet of Cayenne, and a sprinkling of you is excellent:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Well, sir, when you know the state of your own affairs, and to what you have reduced the house, you will perhaps be less ready to grin.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Reduced the house! ha, ha, ha!

div3.stage: Enter Mr. Dornton, with the Newspaper in his hand,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: So, sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Bowing] I am happy to see you, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You are there, after having broken into my house at midnight!—And you are here, [pointing to the paper] after having ruined me and my house by your unprincipled prodigality! Are you not a scoundrel?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, sir: I am only a fool.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Good night to you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Stay where you are, Mr Sulky, I beg you to stay where you are, and be a witness to my solemn renunciation of him and his vices!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I have witnessed it a thousand times:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But this is the last, Are you not a scoundrel, I say?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am your son,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [calling] Mr Smith! Bring in those deeds.
You will not deny you are an incorrigible squanderer?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will deny nothing,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A nuisance, a wart, a blot, a stain upon the face of nature!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A stain that will wash out sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A redundancy, a negation; a besotted sophisticated incumbrance; a jumble of fatuity; your head, your heart, your words, your actions. all a jargon; incoherent and unintellegible to yourself, absurd and offensive to others!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The whirlwind is rising.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am whatever you please, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Bills never examined, every thing bought on credit, the price of nothing asked, conscious you were weak enough to wish for baubles you did not want, and pant for pleasures you could not enjoy, you had not the effrontery to assume the circumspect caution of common sense! And to your other destructive follies, you must add the detestable vice of gaming!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: These things, sir, are much easier done than defended,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But here—Give me that parchment! [To Mr Smith] The partners have all been summoned. Look, sir! Your name has been formally erased!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The partners are very kind.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The suspicions already incurred by the known profligacy of a principal in the firm, the immensc sums you have drawn, this paragraph, the run on the house it will occasion, the consternation of the whole city—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: All very terrible, and some of it very true.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Passionately] Give me the will, Mr Smith! Give me the will! Fond and foolish as I have been, read, and you will find I am at last restored to my senses!—If I should happily outlive the storm you have raised, it shall not be to support a prodigal, or to reward a gambler!—You are disinherited!—Read!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Your word is as good as the Bank, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I'll no longer act the doting father, fascinated by your arts!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I never had any art, sir, except the one you taught me.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I taught you! What? Scoundrel! What?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That of loving you, sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Loving me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Most sincerely!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Forgetting his passion] Why, can you say, Harry—Rascal! I mean, that you love me?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I should be a rascal indeed if I did not sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! Harry! [Struggling with his feelings] No! Confound me if I do!—sir, you are a vile—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I know I am.

sp.speaker: Dorn,
sp.p: And I'll never speak to you more, [Going

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bid me good night, sir, Mr Sulky here will bid me good night, and you are my father!—Good night, Mr Sulky,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Good night:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Come, sir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Struggling with passion] I won't!—If I do—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Reproach me with my follies, strike out my name, disinherit me, I deserve it all and more—But say Good night, Harry!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I won't!—I won't!—I won't!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Poverty is a trifle; we can whistle it off—But enmity—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I will not!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sleep in enmity? And who can say how soundly?—Come! Good night.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I won't! I won't! [runs off.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Say you so?—Why then, my noble hearted dad, I am indeed a scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Good night! [Exit,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Good night! And Heaven eternally bless you, sir! Heigho!—That's something. [Sings,]

lg.l: Time, would let him wisely pass,
Is lively brisk and jolly,
All is not quite as it should be; but— [Sings]
Dip but his wings in the sparkling glass,
And he'll drown dull melancholy,
Heigho! [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE I, The House of the Widow WARREN.

sp.speaker: JENNY,
sp.p: I TELL you, good woman, I can do nothing for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ledger.
sp.p: Only let me see Mrs Warren,

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: And get myself snubbed. Not I indeed.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: La, Jenny! Yonder's my mamma, with a whole congregation of milliners, mantua-makers, mercers, haberdashers, lacemen, feathermen, and—and all the world, consulting about second mourning!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It will be six months to morrow since the death of my father-in-law; and she has been busy giving orders for this fortnight that every thing might be brought home and tried on to-day. I do believe she'll sleep in her new clothes!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How you run on, miss!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What would my dear grandma' say, if she saw her? Why she is even fonder of finery than I am!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Sure, miss, you are not fond of finery?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh but I am—I wonder why she won't let me wear high-heeled shoes! I am sure I am old enough! I shall be eighteen next Christmas day at midnight, which is only nine months and two days! And since she likes to wear slips, and sashes, and ringlets and—nonsense, like a girl, why should not I have high heels, and gowns and festinis, and hoops, and trains, and sweeps [Mimicking] and—like a woman?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: It's very true what your mamma tells you, miss; you have been spoiled by your old fond grandmother in Gloucestershire.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, Jenny, I won't hear you call my dear grandma' names! Though every body told the loving old soul she would spoil me.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: And now your mamma has sent for you up to town to finish your edication.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, she began it the very first day: There was the stay-maker sent for, to screw up my shapes; the shoe-maker, to cripple my feet; the hair dresser, to burn my hair; the jeweller, to bore my ears; and the dentist, to file my teeth.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ah! You came here such a hoyden! [To Mrs Ledger,] What, an't you gone yet, mistress?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, Jenny, how can you be so cross to people? What is the matter with this good woman?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh! Nothing but poverty.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is that all? Here [Rummaging her pocket] give her this half crown, and make her rich.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Rich indeed!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What, is not it enough? La, I am sorry I spent all my money yesterday! I laid it out in sweetmeats, cakes, a Canary bird, and a poll parret. But I hope you are not very, very poor?

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: My husband served the late alderman five-and-twenty years. His master promised to provide for him; but his pitiless widow can see him thrown with a broken heart upon the parish,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh dear!—stop!—stop a bit! [Running off] Be sure you don't go!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where's your mistress girl?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My name is Jane Cocket, sir,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Busy, sir—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Tell her to come down—Don't stare, girl, but go and tell your mistress I want her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aside] Humph! Mr Black and gruff! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I've got it! here! take this, good woman; go home and be happy! Take it, I tell you!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: who is this? Mrs Ledger! how does your worthy husband?

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: Alack, sir, ill enough, likely to starve in his latter days,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: How, starve?

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: The widow refuses to do any thing for him,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: Service, age, and honesty are poor pleas, with affluence, ease, and Mrs Warren,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: You, sir, I understand are the late alderman's executor?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can't tell,

sp.speaker: Mrs Led.
sp.p: Perhaps you may be able to serve my husband?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I don't know—however, give my respects to him: he shan't starve: tell him that.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, but take this in the mean time,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Ay; take it, take it, [Exit Mrs Ledger much affected,] And who are you, miss Charity?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Me, sir? Oh I—I am my grandma's granddaughter.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sophia Freclove,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Oh!—The widow's daughter by her first husband?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, sir,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Coming, sir—so you have stolen your mamma's purse, miss?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, don't say so; I only ran away with it! she was bargaining for some smuggled lace with one of your acquaintance, and I thought I could dispose of her money to better advantage,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Without her consent,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, to be sure! I knew I should never dispose of it in that manner with her consent,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well! here comes your mamma, [Exit.

div3.stage: Enter the Widow WARREN, in a fantastic girlish morning dress, surrounded by Milliners, Mantua-makers. Furriers, Hatters, &c. with their attendants with band-boxes; all talking as they come on.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: So you'll be sure not to forget my chapeau a la Prusse, Mr Mincing?

sp.speaker: Hatter.
sp.p: Certainly not, madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And you'll make a delicate choice of the feathers?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.p: The selection shall be elegant, madam

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes—I know, Mr Mincing, you're a charming man!—And you let me have my pierrot a la Coblentz by nine in the morning, Mrs Tiffany?

sp.speaker: Mantua-maker.
sp.p: To a minute, maim.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Madam, when you have a moment's leisure—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Be quiet, you fright; don't interrupt me!—And my caraco a la hussar, and my bavaroises a la duchesse—And put four rows of pearl in my turban,

sp.speaker: Milliner.
sp.p: Ver vell, me ladyship,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And you'll all come together, exactly at nine?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We'll all be here! [Going,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And don't forget the white ermine tippets, and the black fox muffs, and the Kamschatka furs that you mentioned, Mr Weazel!

sp.speaker: Furrier.
sp.p: I'll bring a fine assortment, madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And, and, and—No; no—you may all go—I can think of nothing else—I shall remember more tomorrow,

sp.speaker: Hatter and Furrier
sp.p: Thank you, madam! All-together

sp.speaker: Mantua-maker and Girls,
sp.p: Very much obliged to you maim!

sp.speaker: Milliner.
sp.p: Dee ver good bon jour to me ladyship.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What was it you were saying, Mr Sulky?—Pray child, what have you done with my purse?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Given it away, ma',

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Given it away, minikin?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes ma',

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Given my purse away! To whom, for what purpose?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, ma', only—only to keep a poor woman from starving,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I protest, child, your grandmother has totally ruined you—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Not quite, madam: she has left the finishing to you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What were you saying, Mr Sulky—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You won't give me leave to say any thing madam

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You know you are a shocking troublesome man, Mr Sulky, I have a thousand things to remember, and can't bear teasing, it fatigues my spirits! so pray relate this very urgent business of yours in a single word—What would you have—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Justice,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord, what do you mean!—Do you think I am in the commission?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes of sollies innumerable!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a sad savage, Mr. Sulky! And who is it you want justice for?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Your late husband's son, John Milford,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Now pray don't talk to me! You are a very intrusive person! You quite derange my ideas! I can think of nothing soft or satisfactory while you are present!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Will you hear me, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I can't, I positively can't, it is an odious subject!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah, ma', how can you be so cross to my brother Milford—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your brother, child—Country education!—how often, minikin, have I told you he is no brother of yours,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, ma', he was your husband's son!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, his—Faugh! Odious word—your brother,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, that he is,—For he is in distress,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And would you now, you who pretend to be a very prudent—ridiculous kind of a person, wish to see me squander the wealth of my poor dear dead good man on Mr Milford, and his profligate companions?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Not I indeed, madam; though the profligate to whom you make love should happen to be one of them

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh the monster,—I make love!—You have no eyes, Mr Sulky! [Walking and exhibiting herself] You are really blind!—But I know whom you mean.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I mean young Dornton, madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To be sure you do,—whom could you mean? Elegant youth!—Rapturous thoughts!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I am sure, sir, young Mr. Dornton is no profligate,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: [Significantly] You are sure?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes that I am!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And it's very scandalous, very scandalous indeed, to say he is my ma's lover!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Because he is a fine genteel young gentleman; and you know ma' is—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, minikin, be less flippant with your tongue.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why la, ma', you yourself know you are too,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go up to your chamber, child,

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I am sure ma', I say it is very scandalous to call the handsome Mr Dornton your lover! [Exit skipping

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Do you blush?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Blush indeed!—Blush, ha, ha, ha; you are a very unaccountable creature, Mr Sulky—Blush at the babbling of a child!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Who is your rival?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! my rival—The poor minikin!—my rival?—But I have a message for you! Now do compose your features to softness and complacency! Look pleasant if you can, smile for once in your life!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Don't make love to me! I'll have nothing to say to you!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Love—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes, you make love to Dornton! Nay you make love to the booby Goldfinch! Even I am not secure in your company!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You are a shocking being, Mr Sulky,—But if you should happen to see Mr Dornton, do astonish your acquaintance: do a good natured thing, and tell him I am at home all day—Love to you? Ha, ha, ha! Oh you figure, you caricatura of tenderness—you insupportable thing! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: [Sighs] Ah!—All labour in vain! [Enter Jenny] stand out of the way girl; [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: There she goes! [Looking after the Widow] That's lucky, this way, sir,

div3.stage: Enter Harry DORNTON, followed by his own Servant with bills in his hand.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My mistress is gone up to her toilette, sir; but I can send you somebody you may like better, [Exit
Harry Obliging Abigail!— [Looking over his papers] 'sdeath, what all these tradesmen's bills?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: All, sir, Mr Smith sent me after you with them,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When were they brought?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Some last night, but most this morning,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ill news travels fast, and honesty is devilish industrious. Go round to them all, return their bills, and bid them come themselves to-day, has Mr Williams the hosier sent in his bill?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, sir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I thought as much—Tell him to come with the rest, and on his life not fail,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Very well, sir, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Oh, Mr Dornton, I am glad to see you, do you know, I've got the song by heart that you was so good as to teach me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And do you know, my charming Sophia, you are the most delightful, beautiful bewitching scholar that ever took lesson,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, Mr Dornton. I'm sure I'm very stupid!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That you are all intelligence, all grace, all wit,

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: To be sure my ma' caught me singing it, and she was pettish; because you know it's all about love and ends with a happy marriage.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But why pettish?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, I can't tell, I suppose she wants to have all the marriage in the world to herself! It's her whole talk! I do believe she'd be married every morning that she rises, if any body would have her!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Think not of her, my sweet Sophia, but tell me—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I dare not ask,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Lest I should offend you,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay now, Mr Dornton, that is not right of you! I am never offended with any body, and I am sure I should not be offended with you! my grandma' always said I was the best tempered girl in the world—What is it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Were you—? [Taking her hand] Did you ever know what it is to love?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, now, how could you ask one such question? You know very well one must not tell!—Besides, you know too one must not be in love—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Because—Because I am but a girl—my grandma' has told me a hundred times, it's a sin for any body to be in love before they be a woman grown, full one-and twenty; and I am not eighteen!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Love they say cannot be resisted,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ah, but I have been taught better!—It may be resisted—Nobody need be in love unless they like: and so I won't be in love, for I won't wilfully do amiss. [With great positiveness] No! I won't love any person though I should love him ever so dearly,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Aside] Angelic innocence! [Aloud] Right, lovely Sophia, guard your heart against seducers.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Do you know it is full five weeks since Valentine's day; and, because I'm not one-and-twenty, nobody sent me a valentine!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And did you expect one?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah—, I can't say but I did think—! in Gloucestershire, if any young man happen to have a liking for a young woman, she is sure to hear of it on Valentine day. But perhaps Valentine day does not fall so soon here as it does in the country;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, it is possible you may yet receive a valentine.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay now, but don't you go to think that I am asking for one; for that would be very wrong of me, and I know better—my grandma' told me I must never mention nor think of such things till I am a woman, full one-and-twenty grown; and that if I were to find such a thing at my window, or under my pillow or concealed in a plumcake—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A plum-cake?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes: I assure you I have heard of a valentine sent baked in a plum-cake—And so if I had one that I must shew it to her. But you know she is in Gloucestershire; And I am sure I would not shew it to ma' for though she is all out and above forty, she would be as jealous as the vengeance! And indeed I would not receive such a thing for the world, no not from the finest man on earth, if I did not think him to be a true and faithful, true, true lover,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But how must he prove his faith and truth?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why first he must love me very dearly!—with all his heart and soul!—And then he must be willing to wait till I am one-and-twenty,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And would not you love in return?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: N—yes, when I come to be one-and-twenty,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Not sooner?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh no!—I must not!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Surely you might if you pleased?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh but you must not persuade me to that! If you do I shall think you are a bad man, such as my grandma' warned me of!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: and do you think me so?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Do I?—No!—I would not think you so for a thousand thousand golden guineas!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Aside] Fascinating purity!—what am I about? To deceive or trifle with such unsuspecting affection would indeed be villiany!

sp.speaker: Goldfinch.
sp.p: [Without at a distance] is she above? must see her—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, I here that great, ridiculous. horse jockey oaf Goldfinch coming up!— [Sighs]—Good bye Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Heaven bless you, Sophia—sweet Sophia, Heaven bless you, my lovely angel! Heigho!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Heigho! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Without] Is she here?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: [Without] I don't know, sir,

div3.stage: Enter GOLDFINCH in a high-collared coat, several under waistcoats, buckskin breeches covering his calves, short boots, long spurs, high-crowned hat, hair in the extreme, &c.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hah; my tight one,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Surveying him] well Charles!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How you stare! An't I the go? That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Where's the widow,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Gone up to dress, and will not be down these two hours,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A hundred to eighty I'd sup up a string of twenty horses in less time than she takes to dress her fetlocks, plait her mane, trim her ears, and buckle on her body-clothes,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You improve daily Charles!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To be sure,—That's your sort!— [Turning round to shew himself] An't I a genus?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Quite an original!—you may challenge the whole fraternity of the whip to match you!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Match me, Newmarket can't match me! [shewing himself]—That's your sort,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh no! Ha, ha, ha! you are harder to match than one of your own pied ponies—A very different being from either your father or grandfather!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Father or grandfather!—shakebags both.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Father a sugar-baker, grandfather a slopseller—I'm a gentleman—That's your sort,

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! And your father was only a man of worth,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Kept a gig! [With great contempt]—Knew nothing,—Never drove four;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, but he was a useful member of society,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A usef—! What's that?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! A pertinent question,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A gentleman like me a useful member of society!—Bet the long odds nobody ever heard of such a thing!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have not acquired your character in the world for nothing, Charles,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: World!—What does the world say?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Strange things—It says you have got into the hands of jockeys, Jews, and swindlers; and that, though old Goldfinch was in his day one of the richest men on 'Change, his son will shortly become poorer than the poorest black-leg at Newmarket,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damn the world!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: With all my heart, damn the world, for it says little better of me,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bet you seven to five the Eclipse colts against the Highflyers, the second spring meeting,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I have done with highflyer and eclipse too—so you are in pursuit of the widow?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Full cry!—Must have her!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! heigho! you must?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: All up with me else! If I don't marry the widow I must smash!—I have secured the knowing one,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Whom do you mean, the maid?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Promised her a hundred on the wedding day.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My mistress can't see you at present, gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Can't see me? [Vexed] Take Harriet an airing in the phaeton,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What is Harriet your favourite?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To be sure, I keep her:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fine creature,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well bred,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Just to my taste—Like myself, free and easy. That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A fine woman?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Prodigious! sister to the Irish giant, six feet in her stockings—That's your sort!—sleek coat, flowing mane, broad chest, all bone,—Dashing figure in a phaeton—sky blue habit, scarlet sash, green hat, yellow ribbands, white feathers, gold band and tassel!—That's your sort,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! heigho,—Why you are a high fellow, Charles!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
To be sure,—Know the odds!—Hold four in hand—Turn a corner in stile!—Reins in form—Elbows square—Wrist pliant—Hayait!—Drive the Coventry stage twice a week all summer—Pay for an inside place—Mount the box—Tip the coachy a crown—Beat the
mail—Come in full speed!—Rattle down the gateway!—Take care of your heads!—Never killed but one woman and a child in all my life—That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aside to Goldfinch] Take him with you [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Want a hedge?—Take guineas to pounds precipitate against Dragon?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Aside] Wish I could have him a few!—Odd or even for fifty? [Drawing his hand clenched from his pocket]

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Odd enough!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will you cut a card, hide in the hat, chuck in the glass, draw cuts, heads or tails, gallop the maggot, swim the hedgehog, any thing?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nothing,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm up to all—That's your sort!—Get him with me and pigeon him. [Aside] Come and see my greys—Been to Tattersall's and bought a set of six—smokers!—Beat all England for figure, bone, and beauty,—Hayait, charmers!—That's your sort!—Bid for two pair of mouse ponies for Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! The Irish Giantess drawn by mouse ponies!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come and see 'em,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Sarcastically] No, I am weary of the company of stable boys,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why so? shan't play you any tricks—If they squirt water at you, or make the colts kick you, tell me and I'll horsewhip 'em—Arch dogs! Deal of wit!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When they do I'll horsewhip them myself,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yourself?—'Ware that—Wrong there!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think I should be right,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you!—What—Been to school?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To school!—Why yes—I—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mendoza—Oh!—Good-morrow! [Exit

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! There goes one of my friends! Heigho!

div3.stage: Enter Milford in haste, followed by Goldfinch returning Eagerly,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What is it Jack? Tell me!

sp.speaker: Milford
sp.p: Come, Harry we shall be too late! They are about to begin, we may have what bets we please:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Where? What?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The great match! The famous Frenchman and Will the marker! A thousand guineas a side!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What tennis?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes, the Frenchmen gives fifteen and a bisque,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To Will the marker?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will for a hundred,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Done, done!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I bar the bet; the odds are five to four already:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What, for the mounseer?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'll take it, five hundred to four.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Done, done!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I bar!—I forget—I have cut, I'll never

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You do for a hundred, [bet another guinea,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Done, done! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What a cake!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But you'll go?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes you will. Come, come, the match is begun every body is there! The Frenchman is the first player

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It's a noble exercise! [in the world!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ay! Cato himself delighted in it,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, it was much practised by the Romans,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The Romans! who are they?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! will you go or will you not, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I can't Jack, my conscience won't let me,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Pshaw! Zounds, if we don't make haste it will be all over,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [In a hurry] Do you think it will? [stops short] No—I won't—I must not,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Taking hold of his arm] Come along, I tell you,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: They have begun:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Have they?—I'm off! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Still struggling, and Harry retreating] what folly! Come along!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, I will not,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Leaving him and going] Well, well, if you're so positive—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Calling] stay Jack; stay—I'll walk up the street with you, but I won't go in,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Double or quits the hundred that you won of me last night you do!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I don't for a thousand!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: No, no, the hundred.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I tell you I won't. I won't go in with you,

sp.speaker: Mil,
sp.p: Done for the hundred!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Done, done! [Exeunt.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the Parlour of the Tennis-court.

div3.stage: Markers passing and repassing with Rackets and Balls.
Sheriff's Officer, two Followers, and one of the Markers

sp.speaker: Marker.
sp.p: Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Pray is Mr Milford, in the court?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I'll bet you gold to silver the Frenchman loses! Hurrah! [Exit.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. SMITH, from the court.

sp.speaker: Mr Smith.
sp.p: He is not there,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: The crowd is very great, but I can neither see him nor any of his companions,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Then he will not come:

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: I begin to hope so!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: [Examing his writ] "Middlesex to wit—One thousand pounds—Dornton against John Milford."

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: You must take none but substanstial bail.— [shout] what a scene!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: He will not be here,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Heaven send!

div3.stage: Enter Goldfinch and a Marker running across

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Is the match begun?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The first game is just over,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Who lost?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: the Frenchman!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damn the mounseers! That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: That's one of his companions. I begin to tremble—stand aside! here they both come,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Which is he?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: The second, [shout.

div3.stage: Enter HARRY DORNTON, MILFORD, in haste.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I hear them! I hear them! Come along,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Harry!—You would not go!—You were determined! [shout.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Zounds! Come along! [Exit in haste.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: [Stopping him] A word with you, sir, if you please

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: With me? Who are you? What do you want!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: You are my prisoner,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Prisoner! Damnation! Let me go!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I must do my duty, sir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Here, here; this is your duty,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: [Advancing] It must not be sir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Mr Smith,—What, at the suit of Dornton?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Yes, sir. 'Tis your own fault for leading his son to these places. He heard you were to bring him here.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Furies!—Marker! [To a Marker passing] Tell Harry Dornton to come to me instantly!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Yes sir, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Zounds! Let me go and fee the match—

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: You must not, sir,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [To another Marker] Marker,

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Who wins?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: The Frenchman has the best on't,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Tell Harry Dornton I am here in trouble, desire him to come this moment,

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Very well sir, [shout.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [To the Officer] I'll give you ten guineas for five minutes!

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Take him away sir,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: You must come along, sir,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [To a Marker returning] have you told him?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: He can't come sir,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Very well, Harry! Very well! [To the second Marker] well, sir,

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: He would not leave the court for a thousand pounds,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Come, come, sir! [To his two attendants] bring him along!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Hands off, scoundrels! [shout] Fiends!

head.stage: SCENE changes to the House of Mr Silky.

div3.stage: A Room of Business, Ledger, Letter-files, Ink-stand, &c.

sp.speaker: Silky.
sp.p: Well, Jacob, have you been?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes sir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, and what news? how is he?—Very bad?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Dead sir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Overjoyed] Dead?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: As Deborah!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Aside] I'm a lucky man! [Aloud] Are you sure he is dead, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I saw him with my own eyes, sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: That's right, Jacob! I am a lucky man! And what say the people at the hotel? Do they know who he is?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh yes, sir!—He was rich! A gentleman in his own country!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And did you take care they should not know you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: To be sure, sir! You had given me my lesson!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Jacob! That's right!—You are a fine boy! mind me, and I'll make a man of you!—And you think they had heard nothing of his having called on me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Not a word!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Aside] It was a luckey mistake! [Aloud] Well, Jacob! Don't say a word, and I'll give you—I'll give you a crown!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You promised me a guinea, sir!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Did I, Jacob? Did I? Well, well! I'll give you a guinea, but be close: did you call at the widow Warren?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes, sir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And will she see me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: She desires you will be there in an hour,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Very well Jacob—Keep close, not a word about the foreign gentleman, or his having been here a week ago, or his being taken suddenly ill and dying! [Aside] It is a lucky stroke!—Close, Jacob, my boy!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But give me the guinea, fir!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What now, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If you please, sir, you may forget—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, there, Jacob; there! you'll be a rich man, Jacob, a cunning fellow, I read it in your countenance, Jacob; close, Jacob, and then—!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll give me another?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well said, Jacob! you'll be a great man, mind what I say to you, and you'll be a great man—here's somebody coming! go, Jacob, close,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And another guinea? [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: This is a luckey stroke, [Enter Goldfinch] so, Mr. Goldfinch what do you want?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Money—a thousand pound directly,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Fine talking, Mr. Goldfinch, money's a scarce commodity, times are ticklish!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tellee I must have it,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Give me but good security, and you know I'm your friend,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, good security and fifty per cent!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Why look you there now, for all you know the last annuity I had of you, I gave a full hundred more than was offered by your friend Aaron, the Jew:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My friend? Your friend! You collogue together,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Hear you now! For all you know I have always been your friend; always supplied you with money, have not I? And when I saw you running to ruin, I never told you of it, did I? I was willing to make all things easy!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Easy enough, you have pretty well 'eased me!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: There is your companion Jack Milford; I shall be a heavy loser by him!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ah! It's all up with poor Jack, he's sixed at last

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Old Dornton has sent the Nab-man after him!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And arrested him?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes he's touched!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Calling] Jacob! [Enter Jacob] Run as fast as you can to my good friend Mr Strawshoe, the attorney, and tell him to take out detainders for all the debts I have bought up against Mr Milford! make haste!

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes, sir, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I thought you were Jack Milford's friend too!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: So I am, Mr Goldfinch; but I must provide for my family,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come, come!—The bit! Tellee I want the coal directly! sale at Tattersall's to-morrow morning! Three Herod brood mares with each an eclipse colt, would not lose 'em for all Lombard-street! so will you let me have the bit?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Dear, dear! I tell you I can't Mr Goldfinch,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Then some other Jew must,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Jew! hear you, hear you, this it is to be the friend of an ungrateful spendthrift, calls me Jew! I who go to morning prayers every day of my life, and three times to tabernacle on a Sunday!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, you cheat all day, tremble all night, and act the hypocrite the first thing in the morning, [Going.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay but stay, Mr Goldfinch, stay I want to talk to you—I have a scheme to make a man of you,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What? Bind me 'prentice to a usurer,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pshaw! you are in pursuit of the widow Warren

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Now what will you give me, and I'll secure her to you,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have a deed in my power, I won't tell you what, but I have it, by which I can make her marry the man I please, or remain a widow all her life; and that I am sure she will never do if she can help it,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You a deed,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Yes I,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Shew it me,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not for twenty thousand pounds—depend upon me, I have it, I tell you I'm your friend, and you shall have her, that is on proper conditions—If not, Mr Goldfinch, you shall not have her,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Indeed, old Judas, well what are your conditions?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I find the late alderman died worth a hundred and fifty thousand pounds,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Every farthing, Mr Goldfinch! And my conscience tells me that, risk and character and all considered, I must come in for my thirds,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your conscience tells you that?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Yes, it does, Mr Goldfinch—Fifty thousand is a fair price,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: For the soul of a miser,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: If you'll join me, say so,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fifty thousand,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not a farthing less! What, will there not be a hundred thousand remaining?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why that's true—it will cut a fine dash.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: To be sure it will! Come with me! I'll draw up a sketch of an agreement. After which we must fight cunning—The widow is a vain weak woman—you must get her written promise,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Written—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Under her own hand; with a good round penalty in case of forfeiture,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well said, old one!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not less than twenty thousand pounds! A jury would grant half!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why you're a good one!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: That would secure something, and we would snack,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Dammee you're a deep one,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha! Do you think I am, Mr Goldfinch—signed on a stamp!

sp.speaker: Gold,
sp.p: You know a thing or two:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha; do you think I do, Mr Goldfinch,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You can teach 'em to bite the bubble,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha! you joke, Mr Goldfinch, you joke.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But the devil will have you at last!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord forbid, Mr Goldfinch, don't terrify me—I hate the devil, Mr Goldfinch; indeed I do; I hate the name of him! Heaven keep me out of his fiery clutches.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No: he has you safe enough, bait his trap but with a guinea, and he is sure to find you nibbling—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Don't talk about the devil, Mr Goldfinch, pray don't; but think about the widow secure her,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I must have the coal though this evening:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Don't lose a moment, Mr Goldfinch;

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Must not lose the eclipse colts—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pshaw, Mr Goldfinch, think less of the colts and more of the widow, get her promise black and white, Goldfinch going

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Turns] Tellee I must have 'em,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: All will then be safe!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Must have 'em. [Exeunt

div3.head: SCENE I, The House of the Widow WARREN,

sp.speaker: JENNY.
sp.p: OH, miss! I have got something for you,

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Something for me, what is it, what is it?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: [Her hand behind her] What will you give me—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh I'll give you [Feeling in her pocket] La, I've got no money, but I'll give you a kiss and owe you sixpence,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No. A shilling without the kiss,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well, well, a shilling:

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: There then, [Giving her a small parcel,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: La, what is it? [Reads] To Miss Sophia Freelove. And such a beautiful seal! it's a pity to break it, [Opening the paper] La, nothing but a plumcake,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Considering] Ecod—ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! I do think—As sure as sixpence it is!—it is—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is what?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Oh la it is!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: What's the matter with the girl?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ecod Jenny, it is the most curious plum-cake you ever saw

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I see nothing curious about it,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh but you shall see, give me a knife—Oh no, that would spoil all,—Look you, Jenny, look—Do but look! [Breaks open the cake and finds a valentine] ha, ha, ha, ha! I told you so! The sweet dear— [Kisses it] Did you ever see such a plum-cake in your whole life, Jenny?—And look here! [Opening the valentine] Oh, how beautiful,—The shape of a honey-suckle—What should that mean?—And two doves cooing, but here!—here's the writing,

lg.l: The woodbine sweet and turtle dove
Are types of chaste and faithful love,
Ah! were such peace and truth but mine,
I'd glady be your valentine.

sp.p: [Repeating] Were such peace and truth but mine, la, now, Mr Dornton, you know they are yours!

sp.speaker: Jen,
sp.p: So, so! Mr Dornton sends you valentines, miss?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh yes. Jenny he is the kindest, sweetest, handsomest gentleman!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: You must give me that valentine, miss,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Give it you:

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes, that I may shew it to your mamma,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Indeed but don't you think it, I would not give this tiny bit of paper, no, not for a diamond as big—as big as the whole world,—And if you were to téll ma', and she were to take it from me, I'd never love you, nor forgive you, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh but indeed, miss, I'm not obliged to keep secrets for nothing,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah, Jenny, you know I am very good to you and here—here!—Don't tell ma', and I'll give you this silver thimble. [Exit Jenny

div3.stage: Enter Widow WARREN and Mr SULKY,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a very shocking person, Mr Sulky,—The wild man of the woods broke loose, do return to your keeper, good Orang Outang; and don't go about to terrify the children!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I tell you, madam, Mr Milford is arrested,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: My brother;

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Locked up at a bailiff's in the next street,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh dear!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And pray now what is that to me,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am not arrested,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Would you were!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh the savage!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The pitiless only should feel pain. The stonyhearted alone should be enclosed by walls of stone,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Don't be cross with ma', sir; I'm sure she'll release my brother,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are sure, minikin!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, ma'; for I am sure no soul on earth would suffer a fellow creature to lie and pine to death, in a frightful dark dungeon, and fed with bread and water:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Your late husband recommended the payment of his son's debts,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Recommended?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But leaving it to my own prudence,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: More's the pity,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which prudence I shall follow,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: It will be the first time in your life—You never yet followed prudence, you always ran before it;

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay come, dear ma', I am sure you have a pitiful heart! I am sure you could not rest in your bed if my poor brother was in prison!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold your prattle, child,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ah! I'm sure you'll make him happy, and pay his debts!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why Jenny! [Calling

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You won't?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Jenny; [Enter Jenny,

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: La, dear sir, have patience—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You are an angel!—And you are—! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Nay pray, sir, do stay! [Exit. following.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am glad the monster is gone! He is a very intolerable person! Pray, Jenny, how did it happen that Mr. Dornton went away without seeing me?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Mr Silky, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Leave us, Jenny. [Exit Jenny] So, Mr Silky—What is this very urgent business of yours?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Looking round] Are we safe, madam? Will nobody interrupt us; nobody over-hear us?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no—But what is the meaning of this caution?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [After fastening the door and carefully drawing the Will from his pocket] Do you know this hand-writing, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah!—It is my poor old dear man's, I see.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You have heard of a will he left in France?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pshaw! Will indeed? He left no will!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Yes, he did, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I won't believe it! He loved me too well to rob me of a single guinea! Poor simple soul! I was his darling!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: His darling madam!—With your permission, I will just read a single clause in which his darling is mentioned! Look, madam; it is thealderman's hand! [Reads] But as I have sometimes painfully suspected the excessive affection which my said wife, Winifred Warren, professed for me during my decline, and that the solemn protestations she made never to marry again, should she survive me, were both done with sinister views, it is my will that, should she marry, or give a legal promise of marriage, written or verbal, that she shall be cut off with an annuity of six hundred a year; and the residue of my effects in that case to be equally divided between my natural son, John Milford, and my wife's daughter, Sophia Freelove.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Six hundred a year! An old dotard! To imagine that a woman of my elegant ideas could exist on six hundred a year! Brute! Monster! I hate him now as heartily as when he was alive: But pray, sir, how came you by this will?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Why it was odd enough! And yet easy enough! My name is Silky, madam—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And you know the executor's name is Sulky—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The gentleman that delivered it only made a mistake of a letter, and give it to Mr. Silky instead of to Mr. Sulky!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And where is that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sil,
sp.p: Ah, poor man! He is dead!

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And gone! Was taken ill the very night he parted from me, went to his hotel, was put to bed in a high fever, and carried off in less than a week.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And does Mr Sulky know of this will being delivered?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Not a syllable! It's all close and smooth!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So much the better—Come, give it me, and—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Excuse me there, madam! I can't do that!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My conscience won't let me! I must provide for my family!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And pray what provision is this will to make for your family, Mr Silky?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Why, madam. I have a proposal—You know the power of your own charms!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which I believe is more than you do, Mr Silky—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Hah! Don't say so, madam! Don't say so!—Would I were a handsome, rich and wellborn youth! But you know Mr Goldfinch?—Ah, ha, ha, ha! I could tell you a secret!

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: What, that he is dying for me, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah! So smitten!—Talks of nothing else!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And is that any secret, think you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The alderman I find died worth more than a plum and a half—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have talked the matter over with my friend, Mr Goldfinch, and he thinks it but reasonable, that for a secret of so much importance, which would almost sweep the whole away, I should receive one third.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fifty thousand pounds, Mr Silky?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I can't take less.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why you are a greater rogue than even I thought you!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord, madam, it's no roguery! It's only a knowledge of the world! A young husband and a hundred thousand pounds, or poor six hundred a year without any husband!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a very shocking old miser, Mr Silky! A very repulsive sort of a person! What heart you had is turned to stone! You are insensible of the power of a pair of fine eyes! But I have made a conquest that places me beyond your reach—I mean to marry Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Surprised] What! Old Mr Dornton, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Old Mr Dornton, man?—I never saw the figure in my life! No! The gay and gallant young Mr Dornton! The pride of the city, and the lawful monarch of my bleeding heart!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Young Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So you may take your will and light your fires with it! You will not make a penny of it in any other way. Mr. Sulky, the executor is Mr. Dornton's partner, and when I marry Mr Dornton he will never inflict the absurd penalty.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No, madam! When you marry Mr Dornton, that he certainly never will! But if any accident should happen to prevent the match, you will then let me here from you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord, good man! Don't mention the horrid idea? Do leave me to my delightful meditations! I would indulge in soft sensibility and dreams of bliss; and not be disturbed by dead men's wills, or the sordid extortions of an avaricious old rogue!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Very well, madam! The secret for the present remains between ourselves! You'll be silent for your own sake! Only remember, ha, ha, ha! If you should want me, I live at number 40. My name is on the door. Ha, ha, ha! Mr. Dornton! Good morning, madam: Mr. Dornton: Ha, ha, ha! You'll send if you should want me? [Exit laughing

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Jenny! [Calling,]

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I was saying, Jenny, pray how did it happeu that Mr, Dornton went away without seeing me?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Indeed ma'am, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel youth!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I'm sure, ma'am, I wonder how you can like him better than Mr. Goldfinch!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr, Goldfinch is very well, Jenny—But Mr, Dornton! Oh incomparable!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I am sure, ma'am, if I was a rich lady, and a handsome lady, and a fine lady, like you, I should say Mr. Goldfinch for my money!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Should you, Jenny? Well, I don't know— [Languishing.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Without] Tellee I must see her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live, here he comes!—He is such a boisterous person! [Goes to the glass] How do I look Jenny? I protest my face is of all colours!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Significantly after examining] You had better go up to your toilette for a minute.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That smooth tongued old extortioner has put me into such a flutter—Don't let him go Jenny.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Never fear, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll not stay too long.

div3.stage: Enter Goldfinch, his Cloaths, Hat, and Boots dirtied by a Fall.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here I am—All alive.

sp.speaker: Jen,
sp.p: Dear! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Safe and sound! Fine kick up!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Have you been thrown?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pitched five-and-twenty feet into a ditch—Souse!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Dear me!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pretty commence! No matter—Limbs whole—Heart sound—That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Where did it happen)

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bye road—Back of Islington—Had them tight in hand too—Came to a short turn and a narrow lane—Up flew a damned dancing master's umbrella—Bounce—Off they went—Road repairing—Wheelbarrow in the way—Crash—Out flew I—Whiz—Fire flashed—Lay stunned—Got up—Looked foolish—Shafts broke—Snarler and Blackguard both down—Black-and-all-black paying away, pannels smashed, traces cut, Snarler lamed.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Terrible!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damned mad!—Cursed a few, cut up Black-and-all-black, horsewhipped Tom, took coach and drove here like a devil in a whirlwind!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: 'Tis very well your neck's not broke!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Little stiff—No matter—Damn all dancingmasters and their umbrellas!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: You had better have been here. Mr Goldfinch. You stand so long, shilly shally, that you'll be cut out at last, If you had but a licence now in your pocket, I'd undertake to have you married in half an hour!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Think? I'm sure on't,

sp.speaker: Gold,
sp.p: Dammee, I'll post away and get one—must not lose her; the game's up if I do—must have her; be true to me, and I'll secure you the hundred, I'll be back from the Commons in a smack!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ah, widow, here am I! [Runs up to her, kisses her boisterously, and dirties her clothes,]

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: I protest, Mr Goldfinch—was ever the like,— [Looking at herself.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Never mind, brush off—I'm the lad—been to Hatchet's—bespoke the wedding-coach,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But—sir—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pannels stripe painted—hammer-cloth fringed—green and white—curtains festooned—patent wheels—silver furniture—all flash—light as a bandbox—trundle and spin after my greys like a tandem down hill—pass—shew 'em the road—whurr—whizz-gig,—That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It will be superb,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Superb? [with contempt]—Tellee it will be the thing!—The go—the stare—the gape—the gaze—the rich widow and the tight one,—there they go—away they bowl—That's your sort,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You have a taste for these things, Mr Goldfinch,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Taste,—believe I have—who more?—Phaetons and curricles, parks and pleasure-grounds—up hill and down—highways and bye-ways"—I'm the boy that shall drive you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pardon me, Mr Goldfinch; if a certain event were by the wise disposition of providence to take place, I should think proper to drive,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You drive, if you do damn me;

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
I'm christened and called Charles—Charles Goldfinch—The knowing Lad that's not to be had—winter and summer—Fair weather and foul—Low ruts
