or no ruts—Never take a false quarter—No, no, widow—I drive—hayait!—Ah,—Ah get on,—St—St—Touch whitefoot in the flank—Tickle snarler in the ear—Cut up the yelper—Take out a fly's eye—Smack crack—That's your sort,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I assure you, Mr Goldfinch, you entertain very improper suppositions concerning—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Go for the licence [going]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay but surely Mr—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Go for the licence—resolved—Taking it here. [Pointing to his forehead]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If retrospect and—and affection threw no other obstacles in the way—yet the—the world—prudence,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The world!—prudence,—damn the world, damn prudence,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh but sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The world nor nobody else has nothing to do with neither your prudence nor mine,—we'll be married immediately,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Immediately, Mr. Goldfinch.!—I— [undecided]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What you won't?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Mr Goldfinch—I—do not—absolutely renunciate—but I—wish

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It was over—Know you do—go for the licence

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray—Dear Mr Goldfinch—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Go for the licence, I tellee.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Only a word,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To the wise—I'm he—go for the licence—That's your sort! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch!—I declare— [Exit following.]

head.stage: SCENE changes to the House of DORNTON.

sp.speaker: Dornton.
sp.p: Still the same hurry, the same crowd, Mr Smith,

sp.speaker: Mr Smith.
sp.p: Much the same sir, the house never experienced a day like this! Mr Sulky, thinks we shall never get through

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Is Milford taken,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: Yes sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Unprincipled prodigal! my son owes his ruin to him alone. But he shall suffer,

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: My young master's tradesmen are waiting,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p:
Bid them come in, [Exit Mr Smith] All my
own fault, my own fond folly! Denied him nothing, encouraged him to spend; and now the unnatural father can coolly think of turning him on the wide pitiless world; there to starve, pine in a prison, rot in dungeons, among agues, rheums and loath someness!

div3.stage: Re-enter Mr SMITH followed by Tradesmen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: This way gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Zounds! what an army—A vile thoughtless profligate!—"Yes, yes, misery be his portion; he merits it;"

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: [To Mr Dornton,] You are wanted in the counting-house sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, I'll be with you in a moment, gentlemen—abandoned spendthrift,

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: I don't like all this, what does it mean?

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Danger,

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: He has been a good customer—None of your punctual paymasters, that look over their accounts,

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Oh, a different thing! Nothing to be got by them—Always take care to affront them,

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Perhaps it is a trick of the old gentleman, to inspect into our charges;

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: I don't like that—rather hear of any tax than of taxing my bill.

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Humph! Tradesmen begin to understand these things, and allow a reasonable profit!

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Can't have less than fifty per cent. for retail credit trade;

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: To be sure not; if a man would live in style, and save a fortune as he ought:

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Hush, mind—All devilish hard run,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly!

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Not a guinea in the house!—To-morrow's Saturday—Hem!

sp.speaker: Dornton.
sp.p: Your servant, gentlemen, your servant.—Pray how happens it that you bring your accounts in here

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: We received notice, sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You have none of you any demands upon me?

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Happy to serve you sir,

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: We shall all be glad of your custom sir,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All, all!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And do you come expecting to be paid?

sp.speaker: First T,
sp.p: Money, sir, is always agreeable,

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Tradesmen find it a scarce commodity:

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: Bills come round quick,

sp.speaker: Fourth T.
sp.p: Workmen must eat!

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: For my part, I always give a gentleman, who is a gentleman, his own time.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I understand you!—And what are you, sir, who seem to stand apart from the rest?

sp.speaker: Hosier.
sp.p: A hosier, sir, I am unworthy the company of these honest gentlemen, who live in style, I never affront a punctual paymaster, not I: and, what they will think strange, I get more by those who do look over their bills, than those who do not,

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Humph! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Second T.
sp.p: Blab!

sp.speaker: Third T.
sp.p: Shab!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And what may be the amount of your bill, sir?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A trisle, for which I have no right to ask,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: No right! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Your son, sir, made me what I am; redeemed me and my family from ruin; and it would be an ill requital of his goodness to come here, like a dun, at such a time as this; when I would rather, if that could help him, give him every shilling I have in the world,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Would you? Would you? [Greatly affected] You look like an honest man! But what do you do here then?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Mr Dornton, sir, knew I should be unwilling to come, and sent me word he would never speak to me more if I did not: and, rather than offend him, I would even come here on a business like this,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Shakes him by the hand] You are an honest fellow—! An unaccountable—and so Harry has been your friend?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Yes sir; a liberal-minded friend; for he lent me money, though I was sincere enough to tell him of his faults.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Zounds sir, how came you to be a weaver of stockings?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I don't know, sir, how I came to be at all; I only know that here I am,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A philosopher!

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I am not fond of titles, sir—I'm a man,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why is it not a shame, now, that the soul of Socrates should have crept and hid itself in the body of a stocking-weaver? give me your bill,

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Excuse me, sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Give me your bill, I tell you! I'll pay this bill myself:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I cannot, must not, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sir, I insist on— [Enter Harry Dornton] so sir, [Turning angrily around] why have you assembled these people into whose debt you have dishonestly run, wanting the power to pay; and who have as dishonestly trusted you, hoping to profit exorbitantly by your extravagance?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Oh, fir, you don't know them! They are very complaisant, indulgent kind of people. Are not you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: First T.
sp.p: Certainly, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Be kind enough to wait a few minutes without, my good friends. [Exeunt Tradesmen] Mr, Williams— [Takes his hand]

sp.speaker: Hosier.
sp.p: Sir— [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How dare you introduce this swarm of locusts here? How dare you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [With continued good humour] Despair, sir, is a dauntless hero.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Have you the effrontery to suppose that I can or shall pay them?—What is it you mean?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To let you see I have creditors.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Cheats! Bloodsuckers!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Some of them: but that is my fault—They must be paid.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Paid!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The innocent must not suffer for the guilty.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You will die in an alms-house!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: May be so; but the orphan's and the widow's curse shall not meet me there!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! Zounds! [Checking his fondness] Paid! Whom do you mean to rob?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My name is Dornton, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you not—? [Wanting words.]

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Quit the room! Begone!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
You are the best of men, sir, and I—! But I hate whining. Repentance is a pitiful scoundrel, that
never brought back a single yesterday. Amendment is a fellow of more mettle—But it is too late—Suffer I ought, and suffer I must—my debts of honour discharged, do not let my tradesmen go unpaid.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You have ruined me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The whole is but five thousand pounds!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: But?—The counter is loaded with the destruction you have brought upon us all!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no—I have been a sad fellow, but not even my extravagance can shake this house.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Bills are pouring in so fast upon us we shall never get through!

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p: [Struck] What!—What is that you say?

sp.speaker: Mr Smith.
sp.p: We have paid our light gold so often over that the people are very surly!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Pay it no more! Sell it instantly, for what it is worth, disburse the last guinea, and shut up the doors!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Taking Mr, Smith aside] Are you serious?

sp.speaker: Mr, Smith.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Impatiently.] Are you serious, I say?—Is it not some trick to impose upon me?

sp.speaker: Mr, Smith.
sp.p: Look into the shop, sir, and convince yourself!—If we have not a supply in half an hour we must stop! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Wildly] Tol de rol—My father! Sir! [Turning away] Is it possible?—Disgraced?—Ruined?—In reality ruined?—By me?—Are these things so?—Tol de rol—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry!—How you look!—You frighten me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Starting] It shall be done!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What do you mean?—Calm yourself, Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay! By heaven!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hear me, Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: This instant! [Going]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Calling] Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Don't droop! [Returning] Don't despair! I'll find relief— [Aside] first to my friend—he cannot fail? But if he should!—why ay, then to Megaera!—I will marry her, in such a cause, were she fifty widows, and fifty furies!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Calm yourself Harry,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
I am calm! Very calm—it shall be done—don't be dejected—You are my father—you were the first of men in the first of cities—revered by the good and respected
by the great—you flourished prosperously!—But you had a son!—I remember it!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why do you roll your eyes Harry,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I won't be long away,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Stay where you are, Harry! [Catching his hand] All will be well, I am very happy, do not leave me,—I am very happy!—indeed I am Harry,—very happy!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tol de rol—heaven bless you, sir! You are a worthy gentleman, I'll not be long:

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hear me, Harry—I'm very happy!

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Mr Smith, sir, desires to know whether we may send to the Bank for a thousand pounds worth of silver

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Furiously] No scoundrel,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Calling and almost sobbing] Harry,—Harry, I am very happy,—Harry Dornton! [In a kind of stupor] I am very happy,—Very happy. [Exit following,

head.stage: SCENE changes to the House of Mr SILKY.

sp.speaker: Silky.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch not called yet, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: No, sir,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nor any message from the widow?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, sir, [Knocking heard]

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: See who knocks, Jacob, [Exit Jacob] I dare say it is one or t'other! They must come to me at last,

div3.stage: Enter Harry Dornton, in wild haste, following Jacob.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: [Entering] Are you sure he is at home?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He is here, sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Mr Silky, [panting]

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah! my dear Mr Dornton, how do you do? I hope you are very well! I am exceedingly glad to see you! this call is so kind, so condescending, it gives me infinite pleasure,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Mr Silky, you must instantly grant me a favour,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: A favour, what is it? How can I serve you? I would run to the world's end,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You must exert your whole friendship!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Friendship, sir? Say duty, 'twas you that made a man of me! I should have been ruined, in the Bench, I know not where or what, had you not come forward
and supported me at the critical moment! And now I can defy the world,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Impatiently] Hear me, I know you can,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh yes! The sum you lent me, a lucky speculation, five years of continual good fortune, and other little lifts have made me, I won't say what—But, your father and perhaps another or two excepted, I say perhaps, I'll shew my head with the proudest of 'em

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why then I am a fortunate man!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: To be sure you are! how can I serve you? what can I do? Make me happy!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You can rescue me from phrensy!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Can I?—I am proud! Infinitely happy!—What? How? I am a lucky fellow! Tell me which way?—Where can I run? What can I do?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Dreading] The request is serious—trying!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: So much the better! So much the better! Whom would I serve, if not you?—You! The son of the first man in the city!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Wildly] You mistake!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I don't! You are, you are! Dornton and Co. may challenge the world, the house of Hope perhaps excepted!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Woefully mistaken!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pooh!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Our house is in danger of stopping payment!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sir?—Stop payment!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My follies are the cause!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Stop payment?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have not been used to ask favours—but—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Stop payment!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Scorn me, curse me, spurn me, but save my father!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Stop payment?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What means this alteration in your countenance?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh dear, no! Ha, ha, ha! Not in the least! Ha, ha, ha! I assure you, I, I, I—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have told you our situation. Yourself and two other friends must jointly support my father, by your credit, to the amount of fifty thousand pounds—Mark me!—Must!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Fifty thousand pounds, Mr. Dornton! Fifty thousand pounds! Are you dreaming? Me? Fifty thousand pounds! Me? Or half the sum? Or a fifth of the sum Me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Prevaricating scound—! Hear me, sir!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [In fear] Yes, sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I must be calm— [Bursting out] Are you not a—! I say—Sir—You have yourself informed me of your ability, and I must insist, observe sir! I insist on your immediate performance of this act of duty!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Duty, and fifty thousand pounds! Are you made Mr. Dornton? Are you mad? Or do you think me mad?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I think you the basest of wretches!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Dornton, I would do any thing to serve you! Any thing, I protest to Heaven!—Would go any where, run—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Of my errands, wipe my shoes! Any dirty menial office that cost you nothing—And this you call shewing your gratitude?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Is it not, Mr Dornton?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [His anger rising] And will you give no help to the house

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Dornton!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: After the favours you have been for many years receiving, the professions you have been daily making, and the wealth you have by these means been hourly acquiring! Will you not, sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Retreating] Nay, Mr. Dornton—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you not, sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Don't hurt a poor old man! I can't!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Seizing, shaking him, and throwing him from him] Scoundrel! [Exit

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Bless my heart! Stop payment?—The house of Dornton!—Fifty thousand pounds? I declare I am all of a tremble! James! William!
Have we any bills on the house of Dornton?

sp.speaker: Fr. Cl.
sp.p: I have just been examining the books, sir, We have bills to the amount of—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: How much? How much? A thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Fi. Cl.
sp.p: Three, sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Three!—Three thousand? Bless my heart!

sp.speaker: Fi. Cl.
sp.p: We heard the news the very moment after young Mr. Dornton came in!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Run, pay the bills away!

sp.speaker: Fi. Cl.
sp.p: Where, sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Any where! Any body will take 'em! Run with them to my dear friend, Mr Smallware; it is too far for him to have heard of the crash. Begone! Don't leave
him Give my very best respects to him! He will oblige me infinitely! Fly! [Exit First Clerk] And go you, James, to the clearing house, and get it whispered among the clerks. Then if there are any of Dornton's bills to be bought at fifty per cent. discount, let me know. I will buy up all I can— [Exit Clerk] It's a safe speculation: I know the house: there must be a good round dividend. [Exit

div3.head: SCENE I, The House of the Widow WARREN,
div3.stage: Enter JENNY followed by Harry Dornton, who with an oppressed heart, but half drunk with wine and passion, assumes the appearance of wild and excessive gaiety.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A WAY, Handmaid of Hecate! Fly!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Lord, sir, you don't mean as you say!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you begone, Cerberea?—Invite my Goddess to descend in a golden shower, and suddently relieve these racking doubts.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Goddess!—I knew you meant miss Sophy!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Prime tormentrix to the Furies, begone!

sp.speaker: Jen,
sp.p: What, sir, to my old Mistress?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hear you?—Yes! I want an old Mistress, with her old gold, instantly to relieve an injured old man—Tol de rol—Vanish, daughter of Nox! Tell her what a gay and love sick humour I am in—Tol de rol.

div3.stage: Enter WIDOW, and Exit JENNY dissatisfied.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Smiling] Mr. Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Widow!—Here am I!—Phaeton the second hurled from my flaming car! I come burning with fierce desires, devoutly bent on committing the deadly sin of matrimony! May these things be? Speak, my saving Angel!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie upon you! How can you throw one into such insuperable trepidation of spirits?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you have me?—Pronounce but the blessed Yes, and I am thine for ever and for aye.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Dear Mr Dornton—! You—I—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Ay, ay—I know very well—The formal No, the crimson blush, the half-consenting side-glance, the
hesitating Yes, the palpitation violent—We'll suppose them all—There, there!—I have acted them over, and parson's tragical farce is going to begin!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, but—! Dear Mr Dornton—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do not imagine, amiable widow, that I am mad!—No, no, no!— [With a hysteric laugh] Only a little flighty—Left my father furiously, drank three bottles of Burgundy franticly, flew in amorous phrensy to the attack, and will carry the place or die on the spot!—Powder and poison await my choice; and let me tell you, sweet widow, I am a man of my word. So you'll have me, won't you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh, Mr Dornton—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why you would not see my father perish! Would you? And me expire! Would you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Am I so very cruel?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then say Yes!—Yes or—Pistols—Daggers—Cannon balls!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, sir, yes, yes!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hold, fair widow! Kind widow, hold! Be not rash!—I am the veriest! villain!—Avoid me!—A ruined—! But that were indeed a trifle—My father! Him! Him have I ruined! Heard you that? Bring forth your hoards! Let him once more be himself, and bid me kiss the dust!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Aside] Elegant youth! [Aloud] Ah you flatterer! I own you have been a little—wild, but—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A little! Oh! Ha, ha, ha! Widow. I am a sad fellow!—A damned sad dog!—I tell you I have ruined my father—A prince of fathers! Who, had I not been a rascal, would have given me his soul! And I have ruined him!—Ruined him!—Beware of me!—Fly me!—Yet should you?—Rise Imps of night! Deep have I sworn to find some means to save a father from destruction, and I will keep my oath though—!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh fie! How can you terrify one so?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And wilt thou, widow, be his support? [Eagerly] Wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel question! How can I deny?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Immortal blessings be upon thee! My father!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will be all rapture to hear—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Will he?—Words of comfort!—Will he?—A buxom, fair and bounteous dame, whose treasures
can restore his tottering fortunes to their wonted splendour! Ha! Will he? Will he?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Certainly, Mr. Dornton, he cannot be displeased at such a choice.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Shakes his head] Ah, ha, ha, ha, [Sighs] You don't know my father! A strange, affectionate—! That loves me—! Oh! He—! And you see how I use him! You see how I use him! But no matter—Tol de rol—We'll be married to-night.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh fie!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay, my Madona! To-night's the day—The sooner the better—'Tis to rescue a father, blithsome widow! A father! To save him have I fallen in love—Remember—Sin with open eyes, widow—Money—I must have money—Early in the morn, ere counters echo with the ring of gold, fifty thousand must be raised!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It shall, Mr. Dornton.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, shall it? Shall it? Speak again, beatific vision, speak! Shall it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tol de rol—He shall live! He shall smile! Again his heart shall feel joy!—Oh my bland and bonny widow! [Partly singing] My widow fair and debonair—Keep thy word—Let but my father be himself, and I am thine! Body and soul thine!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And are your really—? Oh, no!—No— [Coquettishly] You are not in love?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And we'll love by day, and we'll live by night—
With a hey and a ho and a heigho, widow!
I have drunk Burgundy—To your health, auspicious Amazon!—Burgundy!

lg.l: For I wanted the grace [Sings
Of a bold villain's face,
To prevail, with heigho,
On a buxom widow. [Kisses her

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Coquetting] Fie! I shall hate you, if you are so fond of me! I shall indeed!—But no—You are man!—Roving faithless man!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no! Fear not! Thou, gracious widow, art my overflowing cup of consolation—What! A father saved—?—Remember!—Fifty thousand the first thing in the morning?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And would not a part this evening—?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Suddenly] What sayest thou?—Oh, no!—Whoo!—Thousands—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: "No: you are a naughty bad man, and I don't love you: I don't indeed—Else." I have a trifling sum.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Eagerly] How much?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Six thousand—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Six?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which I meant to have disposed of, but—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no! I'll dispose of it, dear widow! [Kisses her] I'll dispose of it in a twinkling! [Elated] Thou art my Goddess! [Kisses her again] By the faith of my body but I will thank thee—Yea thee will love exceedingly!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh fie!—No, you won't!—Will you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will I? [Sighs] Shall I not be in duty bound?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No!—You can love me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! My fair Pelican of Potosi! Queen of Pactolus! Doubt not my gratitude—Let this and this— [Kissing

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie! You are a sad man—But I'll bring you a draft!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do, my blooming widow! Empress of the golden isles, do

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I tell you, you are a very bad man!—But remember, this trifle is for your own use.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, my pearl unparalleled! My father's! My father's! My pocket is an insidious gulf, into which I never more will guineas cast. Save but my father, and I will kiss the ground on which thou treadest, and live and breathe but on thy bounty! [Self-indignation.]
sp.l: At least till time and fate shall means afford
Somewhat to perform, worthy of man and me.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: St!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ah, ha! my merry maid of May!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I suppose you are waiting to see miss Sophy, now you have got rid of the old lady?

sp.speaker: Har,
sp.p:
Got rid of the old lady?—Thou brazen pinplacer, thou virgin of nine-and-twenty years occupation! No. "I have not got rid of the old lady;"
The old lady is to be my blooming, youthful bride!—And I, happy youth, am written and destined in the records of eternity her other half!—"Before the stars were this marriage was decreed—" Heigho.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Lord, sir, what rapturation,—But stay a little, and I'll tell miss Sophy her mamma wants her, here; so then—hush— [Jenny retires, making a sign, and

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: "An't you a sad man?"—Here's the draft,

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Thanks, my Sultana—Thou shall find me very grateful—Thou hast bought and paid for me, and I am thine!—By fair and honest traffic thine!—This halcyon night the priest, pronouncing conjurations dire,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, I won't look at you:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay, to-night we'll marry; shall we not?

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: I'll not answer you a word! [Enter Sophia skippingly, but stops short,] "You are a dangerous man" [Sitting down and coquetting] how dare you talk to me of to-night?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To-night shall be a night of wonder, and we'll love like— [Aside] like Darby and Joan,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Languishing] I shall hate you intolerably!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hey for the parson's permission, hay my sublime widow,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To steal thus upon one at an unguarded moment—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But here first let me kneel, and thus to Ceres pay [Going to kiss her hand in rapture, meets the eye of Sophia,]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: "I'll never forgive you!—I hate you now worse than ever."

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Coming between them with bursting trepidation, taking the valentine from her bosom and presenting it] there sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: There sir,—Oh pray sir, take it sir,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why minikin—I

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: I request sir,—I desire sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Declining it] Tol de rol,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Tearing the paper piecemeal, and throwing it spitefully away] why then there, sir—and there, sir—and there, there, there, there, sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poor minikin! I declare, she is jealous,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Her sobs rising] And I'll—I'll—wri-i-i-ite to my—to my grandma-a-a-a directly,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, child,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And I'll go do-o-o-own—into Glo-o-o-ostershire,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go up to your chamber, child!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And I'll tell my grandma-a what a false, base, bad man you are: and she shall ha-ate you, and despise you; and every body shall ha-ate you, and despise you; and I'll ha-a-ate you, and despise you myself!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poor thing!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And moreover I'll hate and despise all mankind and for your sake [with great energy] I'll live and die a maid!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, child, that I dare be sworn you will,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Widow, I'm a sad fellow, don't have me—I'm a vile fellow, Sophy! You are right to despise me, I am going to marry your mother!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I'll go down into Glo-o-ostershire—I wo-on't live in such a false-hearted city! And you ought to be ashamed of yourself, ma', to make yourself so ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no, sweet Slyth, it is my fault, all my fault!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Enraged] Be gone, miss!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Interposing] Sweet widow! gentle widow,—I've sold myself, Sophy, six thousand pounds is the earnest money paid down, for the reptile Harry Dornton—I love you, Sophy!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How, Mr Dornton?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I do by heaven! Take back your money, widow [Offering the draft] I'm a sad scoundrel,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: You are a base faithless man, you know you are, and you are a pitiless woman, a merciless woman, for all you are my own mother, to let my poor brother Milford go to be starved to death in a dark dungeon.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Milford in prison?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, sir, arrested by your cruel, old, ugly father, I'm sure he is ugly! Though I never saw him in my life, I'm sure he is an ugly, hideous, ugly monster! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Is this true, widow?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Stammering] sir—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Agitated] Arrested by my father?—squandering her money on a ruined reprobate, and won't release her husband's son?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay but, dear Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I'll be with you again presently, widow; presently, presently, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Speaking after him] To-night, you know, Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch is coming up ma'am,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I have no time to waste with Mr Goldfinch. I'll presently send him about his business. Mr Dornton talks I don't know how Jenny—says it must be tonight—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well widow?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not so free, sir! [walks up the stage disdainfully]

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aside to Goldfinch] Have you got the licence?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No—Been to Tattersall's,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: And not for the licence?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tellee I've been to Tattersall's,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ah, It's all over!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Made sure of the eclipse colts—must not lose 'em,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aside] Stupid boody!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Advancing] what is your present business sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My business, ha, ha, ha! That's a good one, I'll tell you my business, [Approaching with open arms]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Haughtily] Keep your distance sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Distance, widow? No; that's not the way, I should be double distanced if I did.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Were you indeed a man of deportment and breeding!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Breeding? look at my spurs,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Had you the manner, the spirit, the—But no—You are no gentleman—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Whew! No gentleman? [Claps on his hat and takes a lounging impudent swagger] Dammee that's a good one!—Charles Goldfinch no gentleman?—Ask in the box-lobby! Enquire at the school! [In a boxing attitude.]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir, you are a tedious person: your company is troublesome!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Turf or turnpike, keep the best of cattle—Walk, trot or gallop—Run, amble or canter—Laugh at every thing on the road—Give 'em all the go-by—Beat the trotting butcher! Gentleman?—That's is your sort!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aside to Goldfinch.] Follow me. [Exit

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I beg, sir, I may not be intruded upon with you or your horse-jockey jargon any more. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here's a kick up. What's all this? Must have her or smash!—Smirker [Pointing after Jenny] will tell me what it means!—Smart thing for a light weight. Spirit, shape, and form—Carry a fine neck in a running martingale—Shews blood—Win all the give and takes—Take her into training—Match her the Abingdon mile against all England—That's your sort! [Exit.

head.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at the House of a Sheriff's Officer.

div3.stage: Enter HARRY DORNTON in the same hurry and Officer.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dispatch, man! Dispatch! Tell Jack Milford I can't wait a moment! Hold—Write an acquittal instantly for the thousand pounds. But say not a word to him of my intention!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: A thousand, sir? It is almost five thousand!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: There are detainders already lodged to that amount.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Five thousand?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Must I write the acquittal for the sum total?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No—Yes, write it however. Have it ready. Early to-morrow morning it shall be paid.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: In the mean time there may be more detainders.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Damnation! What shall I do?—Run, send him! And do you here, a bottle of Champaign and two rummers!—Rummers! Mind!—Not a word to him!— [Exit Officer] Five thousand?—And more detainders!

div3.stage: Enter WAITER with bottle and glasses, and MILFORD following.

sp.speaker: Milford.
sp.p: Mr Dornton!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How now, Jack! What's your wonder? I can't stay a moment with you, but I could not pass without giving you a call. Your hand, my boy! Cheer up!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Excuse me, sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Why, Jack!—Pshaw! Cast away this gloom and be—Honest Jack Milford! You are now in tribulation;
what of that? Why, man, the blessed sum himself is sometimes under a cloud! Wait but till tomorrow—Where is this wine?— [Fills the rummers] Come, drink, and wash away grief! 'Sblood, never look frosty and askaunce, man, but drink, drink, drink!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Abruptly] Sir? I am not disposed to drink!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "Why what a tabernacle phrase is that!" Here's confusion to all sorrow and thinking!—I could a tale unfold—! But I won't afflict you—I must fly—Yet I can do no good to-night— Hurrah, Jack! Keep up your spirits! Be determined, like me!—I am the vilest of animals that crawl the earth—Yet I won't flag!—I'll die a bold face villain! I have sold myself—Am disinherited—Have lost—Ah, Sophia!—Hurrah, Jack!—Keep it up!—Round let the great globe whirl; and whirl it will, though I should happen to slide from its surface into infinite nothingness—Drink, my noble soul!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Your mirth is impertinent, sir!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: So it is, Jack!—Damned impertinent! But ruin is around us, and it is high time to be merry!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Sir? I must inform you that, though I have been betrayed by you and imprisoned by your father, I will not be insulted!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Betrayed by me?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ay, sir! I have had full information of your mean arts! It was necessary I should be out of the way, that your designs on Mrs. Warren might meet no interruption!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pshaw!—Good day, Jack, good day!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And pray, sir, inform your father I despise his meanness, and spurn at his malice!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Suddenly returning and darting on him, but stopping short] Jack Milford!—Utter no blasphemy against my father!—I am half mad!—I came your friend.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I despise your friendship!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That as you please—Think all that is vile of me I defy you to exceed the truth—But utter not a word against my father!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Deliberately, pitifully malignant!—Not satisfied with the little vengeance he himself could take, he has sent round to all my creditors!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Tis false!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: False?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A vile, eternal falsehood!

div3.stage: Enter OFFICER with papers and writs,

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Gentlemen!—Did you call?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Interrupting him] Leave the room, sir!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: But—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: We are busy, sir!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I thought—!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I tell you we are busy, and must not be interrupted! [Exit Offcer] [Pause of consideratiou] Mr. Milford, you shall hear from me immediately.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [After ruminating] What were those papers? Surely I have not been rash?—Nobody but his father could have brought my creditors thus on me all at once?—He seemed half drunk or half frantic!—Said he was ruined, disinherited—Talked something of to-morrow—What could the purport of his coming be? [Enter Officer] Well, sir?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Here is a note, sir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: The young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Reads aside] 'I understand you are liberty'—How! At liberty? [The Officer bows] [Reads] I shall walk up to Hyde Park: you will find me at the Ring at six—Exactly at six'—At liberty?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Your debts are all dischared.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Impossible!—Which way?—By whom?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Why, sir—That is—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: No hesitation, but tell me by whom?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Sir—I thought I perceived some anger between you and the young gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Ask no questions, sir; make no delays! Tell me who has paid my debts?—Tell me the truth—Consequences you do not suspect depend upon your answer!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: I perceive, sir, there has been some warmth between you: and though the young gentleman made me promise silence and secrecy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: [Astonishment] What then it was Mr. Dornton? [Officer bows] Madman! What have I done! [Exeunt.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the House of DORNTON.

div3.stage: Enter HARRY DORNTON, followed by Mr. SMITH.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And the danger not yet past?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Far from it! Mr. Sulky has twice brought us supplies, and is gone a third time.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Brave spirit! He would coin his heart!—My father supports it nobly?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: He is anxious only for you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well, well! Ha, ha, ha! Tol lol—I'll bring him relief—Comfort him, assure him of it!—Ay, hear me heaven and—! To-night it is too late, but to-morrow all shall be well!—Excellent well!

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: [Significantly] You will marry the widow?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Have you heard?—Ay, boy, ay!—We'll marry! "I will go and prepare her—We'll marry!"—Early in the morning that all may be safe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Will that be right?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "I have told her the truth. She knows all: knows what a vile infernal—I tell you she knows me! My father again shall look upon the glare of the day! First to the proctor, next to the lawyer, and then—! Ha, ha, ha! Ay then to my fair bride! Hearest thou, my noble soul? I say my bride! My fair, my blooming, thrice-bedded bride! No novice she, old true blue! Tol de rol—It will be a merry wedding! Console my father! Cheer him! Enlighten his soul with hope! I'll keep my word; What, does he not know me? Am I not his own son?—Why, ay— [Looking at his watch] The proctor's, the lawyer's, the widow's, and [Starts] at six?— [Aside] The Ring?—The Ring at six? Fiends!—Who can say what may happen?—What, leave my father to perish?—I'll not go! Though all hell should brand me for a coward, I'll not go!—Mr. Smith, take care of my father!—Mark me, I recommend my father to you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Where is Harry?—Did not I hear his voice?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He is this moment gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Gone where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: Do you not suspect where, sir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Suspect!—What?—Speak?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: To the widow Warren's.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: For what purpose?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: To marry her.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Marry!—The widow Warren!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: And save the house by her fortune.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Generous Harry! Noble affectionate boy! I'd perish first!

sp.speaker: Mr. Sm.
sp.p: He seems very resolute—He has already had six thousand pounds of her.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Marry her? I shall go mad!—Where is Mr. Sulky?

sp.speaker: Mr Sm.
sp.p: He is just returned, I hear him in the compting-house,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Tell him I wish to speak with him, [Exit Mr Smith] Harry Dornton and the widow Warren? I shall die in Bedlam! [Enter Mr Sulky] Are we safe, Mr Sulky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: For to-day, perhaps,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What bank have we to begin to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can't tell—I fear not thirty thousand.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mr Sulky, you—you—have this day shewn yourself an active partner, and a sincere friend.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I have long esteemed you; I esteem you more and more,

sp.speaker: Sul
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: My son Harry— [Hesitating] You are a very good man, Mr Sulky; a compassionate man, though you don't look so,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to see so noble a youth—I am sure you would not wish him any harm, Mr Sulky, I am sure you would not!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry Dornton, would you—would you—would you, Mr Sulky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: A kind question,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Nay, I did not mean to be unkind, Mr Sulky, you know I did not—shall we not venture one step more to save him?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Save? Impossible! Ruin only can reform him; total ruin.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You mistake, Mr Sulky, his own misfortunes little affected him, but mine—he is struck to the heart—I know him.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Dorn,
sp.p: Struck to the heart—I'm sure on't! he'll be a good man!—A great man,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You know the widow Warren, Mr Sulky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Don't you?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I never saw her in my life—I hear she is full forty, her manners absurd, her character cruel, and her morals—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Bad enough,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Six thousand pounds at this moment is a great sum! I own it! But do you think I ought not to venture?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Venture what?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: To—To take it from our bank?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: For—For the—the relief of Harry Dornton?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What you please, take all! what is it to me?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Nay, but, Mr Sulky, you surely don't see the thing in the right light?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can starve, like the rest!

sp.speaker: Dorn,
sp.p: [Snappish haste] Very well, Mr Sulky, very well: I perceive you can be interested, and—and—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And what?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, Mr Sulky, very well!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I can stare bankruptcy in the face as stedfastly as you can.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Ay, ay. No doubt! The world is all alike! I am an old fool, and so shall live and die:

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Why do you ask my advice? Take the money. Empty the coffers! Pour it all into his hat, give him guineas to play at chuck farthing, and bank bills to curl his hair.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Very well, Mr Sulky:—Friendship, generosity, a sense of justice. Oh, it's all a farce,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Humph,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Rings] Very well, sir: Very well, [Enter servant] Is the carriage ready?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: It's at the door, sir, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Going, turns back] So, Mr Sulky, you could see him married to this widow, to whom you have so often as well as now given the worst of character, rather than incur a little more risk for your friend.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Marry?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Yes, marry,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The widow Warren, I tell you!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And Harry Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Yes, and Harry Dornton,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: When, where?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Immediately, with unexampled affection, to save me who am old and worthless, he would devote his youth, his great quailities, and his noble heart, to all the torments which such a marriage and such a woman can inflict

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Take the money!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you serious, Mr Sulky,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Take the money, away, begone! I would indeed starve, inchmeal, rather than he should marry her,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mr Sulky, you are a worthy man, a true friend.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Curse compliments, make haste. [Exeunt

div3.head: SCENE The Widow WARREN'S, SOPHIA and JENNY meeting.

sp.speaker: JENNY.
sp.p: So, miss! here's your mamma just coming down,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [Much agitated] Is she dressed?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh yes!—I have decorationed her out like any king's coach horse,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It's very well.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: With her ribbands and ringlets stuck about and dangle-ating down her back and all here—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It's very well.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Tight laced—"Thomas called up to help."—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: It's all very well!—But it will be no wedding,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: [Aside] I hope not;

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: He told her to her face that he loved me, and offered to give her the money back—He'll never have her—And if he does I don't care—I know I shall die broken-hearted, but I don't care—I'll tell all to my dear grandma', for I'll not stay in this wicked city—No i he shan't see me pine away—I know my ghost will haunt him; but I can't help it. I never wished him any harm, and had he but been true-hearted and have waited for me, I would—But it's no matter—He shan't see a tear that I shed, nor hear the least sigh that I heave.

sp.speaker: Jen:
sp.p: [Looking, admiring, and walking round her] Well, ma'am—! I declare you're a pictur!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you think I look tolerably, Jenny? [Walking and surveying herself]—Shall I do execution? What is the matter, child?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Mark my words, he'll never have you!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poor thing!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: He never will!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Run, Jenny, see who it is! [Exit Jenny] Go up to your chamber, child.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No! I will stay here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Begone to your chamber, I say, miss!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Beat me if you please, kill me, but I will not!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Here's an elderly gentleman, ma'am, asks to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you begone, miss?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Since it is not he I don't want to stay. I only want to look him in the face once more. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How is he dressed?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: In grey ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In gray? [Considering.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In dark gray? [Hoping.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Earnestly] Does he look like a parson, Jenny?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why ma'am he is a soberly, snug, jobationlooking man enough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let him be shewn in—I dare say it is the Divine!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Your humble servant, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir your very most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I presume you are unacquainted with me?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Simpering] I believe I can penetrate, sir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Can you, madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [With her fan before her face] You—You come on the—part of—young Mr. Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Surprised] I do!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Aside] It is the parson!—Would you be so indulgent as to be seated, sir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Excuse me, madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Would you be pleased to take any refreshment, fir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Madam?—None, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A morsel of seed-cake, a French biscuit, a bit of orange-loaf, a glass of Constantia, or a jelly?—I know these little cordial comforts are agreeable consolations to gentlemen of your cloth.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Surveying himself] Cloth!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No offence, I hope? I participate in them myself.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hem! No doubt!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are acquainted with Mr. Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why—Yes—I am I believe one of his oldest acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then I dare say you have a great regard for him?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Hem!—Yes—I—had a—sort of a friendship for him even before he was born.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir!—Oh!—You are intimate With the family?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Yes—yes, madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And know his father?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Um— [Shrugs] Why—Though I have kept him company from the day of his birth to this very hour, they tell me I don't know him yet!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ay indeed, is he so odd?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Sometimes—To my great regret, I have sometimes found him a very absurd old gentleman,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am sorry for it—Because as I am soon to become—hymeneally—his intimate—relation—I—I—!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: You would wish for a sensible indulgent—Papa— [Smiles.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It's natural sir, [Simpering.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Ha, I dare not say too much in his favour,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay though I have a vast—hum—ha—regard for young Mr Dornton—I own I have no great predilection of opinion for the father!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Suddenly] Nor he for you, madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I am sure so!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I warrant, sir, he is, as you say, a very precise acrimonious person—A tetchy repugnant kind of old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I said no such thing, madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah! a little caution, sir, to be sure, becomes gentlemen of your cloth,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p:
Cloth again!—I don't know what you mean
by my cloth: but Mr Dornton, madam, is little older than yourself: nor does he think himself half so repugnant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir,

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Recollecting himself] Madam—I—I beg your pardon,—I— [Bowing.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Knocking heard] Oh! here I dare comes the bridegroom, [Enraptured, crosses to the door.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Aside] My curst vivacity! I can never tell her after this who I am. [Walks up the stage.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh you rover,

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, my kind widow! [Mr Dornton turns quick round at hearing his Son's voice, and gradually approaches] My loving compassionate widow! I am come post haste to cast myself once more on your bounty,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hu-sh!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To intreat instant commiseration, and aid,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hem, hem! [Aloud.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have not a minute to spare!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Whisper] He's here, he's come! A waspish, tetchy—! Hem— [Aloud] Your friend has been here some time, Mr Dornton.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My friend, what friend?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your friend the clergyman.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Clergyman—You— [Turning, sees his Father at his elbow]—My father!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: His father, [Pause.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Well, Harry, why do you look so blank? I am glad you are here—Your coming, and the mutual sincerity with which this lady and I have just spoken, our sentiments, will save all circumlocution—At present we understand each other.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir—I—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Oh, madam, never retract—Let us continue the like plain honest dealing—

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: But—sir—Mr Dornton's affection—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Affection, madam!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry—I know your motives, will never forget them! But the cause of them has ceased.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir?—Beware! No false compassion! Remember not the vile reprobate that was your son! I spurn at existence that his coupled with your misery!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! our danger his over.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Are you—? Are you serious?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Mr Sulky is a worthy man! his rich uncle is dead, and has left him sole heir. Our books too have been examined, and exceed our best hopes,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tol de rol—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Here is your money, madam.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father saved—Tol de rol!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay but—Mr Dornton,—sir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I must beg you'll take it—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Rejoice widow! Rejoice! sing, shout! Tol de rol!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I do not want the money, sir! Filthy money— [Wimpering restrained] And as to what I said, though you have arrested Mr Milford—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha! [starts, considers, and looks at his watch.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am sorry—I beg your pardon—And if Mr Dornton—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Why don't you speak, Harry? Where are you going? [Harry Dornton crosses hastily to the door] Come back, Harry!—stay, I say!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I cannot stay!—I must fly—My honour is at stake, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Alarmed] His honour,—his honour at stake! here, here, madam!— [Offering her Bank bills.]

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, sir—

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, madam, take your money, [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel—usage!—Faithless—men—Blind—stupid! I'll forsake and forswear the whole sex!

div3.stage: Enter JENNY with glee on tip-toe, as if she had been on the watch.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: [Sobbing] Savage race,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ma'am, ma'am! Mr Goldfinch, ma'am

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hay! Mr Goldfinch?—was that what you said, Jenny? [Brightens up] Where?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Below, ma'am. I persuaded him to come up, but he is quite surly,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh! he is coming, well! I think I will see him—Yes—I think I will,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I always told you, ma'am, Mr Goldfinch for me,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Did you?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: But he says he will have your written promise this very night, or never speak to you more—I hear him. [Adjusting the widow's dress] Law. ma'am, you had better give a few touches—hereabout! Your eyes will have double the spirit and fire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will they? [Exit.

sp.speaker: Goldfinch.
sp.p: Where's the Dowager?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hush! mind what I said to you—It is too late now for a licence, so be sure get the promise—Don't flinch—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Me flinch? Game to the back-bone!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hush,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here I am once more, widow,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ah, rambler!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Are you cured of the tantarums?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Goldfinch—!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Must I keep my distance?

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Unkind!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Am I a gentleman now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Killing!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Look you, widow, I know your tricks—Skittish! Won't answer the whip! Run out of the course! Take the rest!—So give me your promise.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My promise—!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Signed and sealed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Naughty man—You shan't—I won't let you tyrannize over a palpitating heart!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Palpi— [To Jenny] What does she say?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You shan't steal on hymeneal transports!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Connubial ecstasies!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nu—What?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go, intruder!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh! What you won't?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll never forgive you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm off.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cruel man!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm off.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr Goldfinch! [Calling]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm off—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You shall have the promise!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh, ho! Why then I pull up—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Barbarous youth! Could you leave me?—But I must send to Mr Silky.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No, no! Let me have the promise directly! I'll go myself to Silky.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you. Mr Goldfinch?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will I not?—Take a hack, mount the box—Hayait!—Scud away for the old scoundrel! I'm a deep one! Know the course every inch! I'm the lad for a widow! That's your sort!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Saucy man! I'll be very angry with you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Soon be back!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Adieu! Fly swiftly, ye minutes!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But I must have the promise first!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will go and write it—Come, dissembler, come!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: She's an old courser! But I know I should take her at the double!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: So, Charles, where's the widow?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The widow's mine!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yours?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'm the lad! All's concluded—Going post for old Silky. [Offers to go at every speech, but is eagerly stopped by Milford.]

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Silky did you say?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Am to pay the miserly rascal fifty thousand pounds down! But mum! That's a secret!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You are raving!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tellee he has her on the hip! She can't marry without his consent!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Don't know. The close old rogue won't tell. Has got some deed, he says—Some writing.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
Yes—But it's all hush! I shall be a higher fellow than ever, Jack! Go to the second spring meeting—Take you with me—Come down a few to the Sweaters and Trainers—The knowing ones—The Lads—Got into
the secret—Lay it on thick—Seven hundred to five Favourite against the field!—Done!—I'll do it again!—Done!—Five times over ditto repeated!—Done, done! Off they go!—Winner lays by—Pretends to want foot—Odds rise high! Take 'em—Winner whispered lame—Lags after—Odds higher and higher!—Take 'em—Creeps up—Breathes 'em over the flat—Works 'em up hill—Passes the distance post—Still only second—Betting chair in an uproar!—Neck to neck!—Lets him out—Shews him the Whip!—Shoots by like an arrow—Oh dammee a hollow thing!—That's your fort! [Exit

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Fifty thousand to Silky for his consent because of some deed, some writing?—If it should be the—? It must!—By heaven it must! [Exit hastily.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the Ring in Hyde Park.

div3.stage: HARRY DORNTON, looking at his watch.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How long must I wait?—I see nothing of Milford—I'll cut off that bailiff's ears if he have betrayed me. [Walks about.]

div3.stage: Enter Mr. DORNTON, out of breath.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: So, Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father again!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Panting] What do you do here, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir—I—I want air.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: So do I—A pretty dance you have led me—What brought you hither?— [Sudden recollection] Where's the money you had of the widow? [Pause seeming to dread an answer] Where's the money, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Reluctantly] Gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Most of it.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And your creditors not paid? [Another pause] And your creditors not paid?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [Raises his hands] I suspected—I foreboded this! [Harry Dornton walks up the stage] He has been at some gaming house, lost all, quarrelled and came here to put a miserable end to a miserable existence! Oh, who would be a father! [Extreme anguish]

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p:
I am sent on an April-day kind of errand here. I think this is what they call the Ring [Look round.]
Hey! Who is this? [Surveying Mr Dornton] Pray—Sir—Is your name Dornton?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Wai.
sp.p: Then I am right—Mr Milford, sir, has sent me this note.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Advancing] It is for me, sir!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: How do you know, Harry?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, I am certain!—I must beg—!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: This is no time for ceremony! [Reads] Dear Harry, forgive the provocation I have given you; forget the wrong I have done your father—Me!—I will submit to any disgrace rather than lift my hand against your life—I would have come and apologised even on my knees, but I am prevented—J. Milford. [Stands a moment crumbling up the letter]—Why Harry!—What! What is this?—Tell me—Tell me—Is it in paying Milford's debts you have expended the money?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It is, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [After raising his clasped hands in rapture as if to return thanks, suddenly suppresses his feelings] But how had he wronged me?—Why did you come here to fight him?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir—He—he spoke disrespectfully of you.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: [With his eyes fixed on his son, till unable any longer to contain himself he covers them with one hand and stretches out the other] Harry!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Taking his father's hand, but turning his back likewise to conceal his agitation] My father! [Pause]

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry! Harry! [Struggling affection] [Pause]

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear sir, let us fly to console poor Milford!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: What you will, Harry! Do with me what you will—Oh who would not be a father [Exeunt.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the House of the Widow Warren.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: The fool Go ldfinch himself informed me, sir, that Silky is to receive fifty thousand pounds for his consent!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Fifty thousand! Zounds! Why then the old scoundrel must have got possession of the will.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p:
Which is ind ubitably meant to be destroyed. Goldfinch is just returned with Silky. They are now with
the widow, all in high glee, and are coming up here immediately, no doubt to settle the business in private.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: We must hide ourselves somewhere, and spring upon them.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I hate hiding! It's deceit, and deceit is the resource of a rascal.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But there is no avoiding it! We cannot get legal assistance in time! Here are two closets! Do you go into one, and I'll shut myself up in the other. We shall hear what they are about, and can burst upon them at the proper moment.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Well, if it must be so—But it's a vile, paltry refuge!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I hear them coming! Make haste!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Sulky and Milford into the closets.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I told you, madam, I should hear from you when you wanted me! I knew it must come to that! But you are a lucky man. Mr Goldfinch, and I'am a lucky man! ay and you are a lucky woman too, madam! We are all in luck!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay dammee, old one, you have been concerned in many a good thing in your time!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha, ha! To be sure I have! I must provide for my family, Mr. Goldfinch!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is indeed a fortunate event! Do you not participate my raptures, Mr Goldfinch?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To be sure—It's a deep scheme! It's knowing a thing or two! Hay, old one? Pigeoning the Green horns!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: All so safe too, so snug! I am so pleased, and so happy! It's all our own! Not a soul will know of it but our three selves!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh yes—One more, old one—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Ay! Who? Who?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your father—Beelzebub!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord! Mr Goldfinch, don't terrify me!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To be sure, it must be owned you are a shocking old rogue, Mr Silky! But there is no doing without you—So make haste with your deeds and your extortions; for really we should be glad to be rid of your company—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, well, I'm ready—I'll not long interrupt your amorous haste. I am a man of business! I expected how it would be, and have a legal instrument here, ready drawn up by my own hand; which, when it is signed and sealed, will make all safe!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But where is the will?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Oh I have it—First however let us be secure. [Locks both the chamber doors: is going to read, but looks round, sees the closet doors, and with great anxiety and cunning locks them too.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You're an old trader in sin! There's no being too deep for you!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha! Do you think so, Mr Goldfinch?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But I should like to see you on your death-bed!
sp.stage: [A blow from one of the closets.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Bless my soul!—What's that?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Zounds! Odd enough! I believe he's coming for you before your time!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It was very strange!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I declare I am all of a tremble!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, come, let us get the shocking business over!—Where is the will?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Don't shake so man!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, well!—First sign the bond! [Widow and Goldfinch going to sign, another knock heard] Lord have mercy upon me!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I smell sulpher!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Save me, Mr Goldfinch!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The candles burn blue! [Pause

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pshaw! Zounds, it is only some cat in the closet!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I heard it in both the closets!

sp.speaker: Gold,
sp.p: Why then there are two cats!—Come! I'll sign—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Where's the promise?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here it is! [Laying it on the table

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And here is the will, which, that all may be safe, we will immediately commit to the flames. [Is going to burn it at the candle. Four successive loud knocks are heard, one from each of the doors. Silky starts, drops one candle, and overturns the other. The stage dark,]

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lord have mercy upon us!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My hair stands an end!
sp.stage: [Violent knocking at both closets and at the doors.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Save me, Mr. Goldfinch! Protect me! Ah!

div3.stage: [Sulky and Milford burst open the closets and seize on the bond and promise: then open the chamber doors, at one of which enter Jenny with lights, and at the other Sophia, Harry Dornton, and Mr Dornton.]

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Dear, ma', what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Where is the will? [Silky recovers himself and snatches it up] Give it me, you old scoundrel! Give it me this instant, or I'll throttle you!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: So, gentlemen! You are a pretty pair of knaves!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And you are a very worthy lady!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Don't talk to me, man!—Don't talk to me!—I shall never recover my senses again!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What has happened, gentlemen? How came you thus all locked up together?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Are you here, Mr. Silky?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Yes! There's the honest, grateful, friendly Mr. Silky! Who would betray his friends, plunder the living, and defraud the dead, for the ease of his conscience, and to provide for his family!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Old one! You're done up!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And here is the girlish old coquette, who would rob her daughter and leave her husband's son, to rot in a dungeon, that she might marry the first fool she could find.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Widow! You are dished! [Sulky examines the will] Lost your last chance!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: A broken gamester, nurtured in idleness, ignorance, and dissipation, whose ridings, racings, and drivings are over, and whose whole train of horses, dogs, curricles, phaetons, and fooleries must come to the hammer immediately, is no great loss.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh, la! And what is coming to the hammer?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Oh, the hammer is an instrument by which Folly is publickly knocked down to the best bidder; after which she rises, gambols, whisks away, makes a short flying tour, and gallops back to be publickly knocked down again.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: "Dear!—Poor Mr Goldfinch,"

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: I knew your father, sir: 'tis happy for him that he is dead! If you will forsake these courses and apply to trade—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Damn trade; Who's for the spring meeting? Cross 'em and wind 'em! seven to five you don't name the winner! I'm for life and a curricle! A cut at the caster, and the long odds! damn trade, the four aces, a back hand, and a lucky nick! I'm a deep one: That's your sort! [Exit,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And now, madam—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Keep off, monster! You smell of malice, cruelty and persecution!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: No, madam: I smell of honesty! A drug you nauseate, but with which you must forcibly be dosed;—I have glanced over the will, and find I have the power:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let me go, goblin!—You are a hideous person, and I hate the sight of you! Your breast is flint!—Flint! Unfeeling Gorgon, and I abominate you:

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nah, you are a kind, good, cross old soul; and I am sure you will forgive my poor ma', we ought all to forget and forgive: Ought not we, Mr Dornton,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [With rapture, and looking to his father] do you hear her, sir?

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: Harry has told me of your innocent, pure, and unsuspecting heart—I love you for having called me an ugly monster;

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: [To Harry] La, Mr Dornton, how could you!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Harry—Give me your hand—You have a generous and a noble nature! But your generosity would have proved more pernicious than even your dissipation. No misfortunes, no not the beggary and ruin of a father, could justify so unpricipled a marriage!

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: And now [To Mr Sulky] my friend,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: My father—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My—!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Whoo! If you wish to get another word from me to night, have done. [Turning to Silky] I hate fawning!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, Mr Sulky, you will have your humour,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: The undiscriminating generosity of this young man supported you in your day of distress; for which, serpent-like, you turned to sting your preserver,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Ah, you will have your humour,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p:
Yes; and it is my humour to see that your villany shall be exposed in its true colours. Hypocrisy, falsehood, and fraud, are your familiars. To screen
your avarice, you made it believed that this gentleman had been the cause of lodging the detainders, and had done the dirty work of which even you were ashamed. But the creditors receive their full demand.

sp.speaker: Dorn.
sp.p: The proposal is just. Listen to that worthy man; and if you can, be honest with a good grace. Every thing will then be readily adjusted, and I hope to the satisfaction of all parties.
